posts.text:
There is a significant gap between developers‚Äô ideal workweek and their actual workweek.

Here‚Äôs what a recent paper published by Microsoft Research, surveying ~6000 engineers, found:

‚ÄúDevelopers want to spend more time on core development activities such as coding, designing new systems, learning new technologies, and sharing knowledge, while wanting to reduce the time spent on tasks related to security and compliance, communication, debugging, addressing incidents and support tickets, and task management.‚Äù

So, developers genuinely enjoy coding, learning, and presenting their knowledge to others!

However, most AI coding tools today only focus on writing code, the very task developers actually enjoy!

This means most of the real pain points remain unresolved. 

Yeh, coding assistants are cool, but they barely scratch the surface of what‚Äôs possible.

According to the study, these are the top tasks developers desperately want to automate:

1. Documentation
2. Environment setup and maintenance
3. Writing and maintaining tests
4. Task tracking and backlog management
5. Security and compliance

The takeaway: 

There are huge opportunities to create great AI products for developers beyond coding tools.

Because modern AI agents can ingest every corner of a large project.

What‚Äôs coming is a brutal meritocracy, where only new contributions count.

posts.text:
Sometimes I get asked how I manage to get so much stuff done.*

I don‚Äôt have a straightforward answer, but today I want to share a productivity hack that has worked very well for me.

üëâ Use a cube timer (like the one in the picture below). You just flip it to set 5, 10, 30, or 60 minutes.

It works!

This little thing is a real productivity booster because:

1Ô∏è‚É£ We are all pretty bad at estimating how long it takes to complete most tasks.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Lazy people (like me) often need a kicker to pick up the right pace and keep momentum.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Having no time for anything else allows me to focus for short periods of time on a SINGLE task.

Here are my two favorite ways to use it:

‚úÖ To gamify tiny tasks under strict time constraints:
‚Üí e.g., I gave myself a max of 10 minutes to write this LinkedIn post.**

‚úÖ To get deep focus time without interruptions:
‚Üí e.g., I can agree with the family not to be disturbed for, say, 1h, and everyone can see the timer counting down.

Give it a try!

* Productivity and the ‚Äúamount of things done‚Äù are very subjective matters, so whatever metric works for you is probably right.

** I already had in mind what this post would be about (that‚Äôs another trainable mental process for which I‚Äôve developed some other tactics), and I spent 1 extra min taking the picture.

In yesterday‚Äôs episode, uhm, I mean‚Ä¶ talk by Andrew Ng ‚ÄúBuilding Faster with AI,‚Äù he mentioned something interesting:

üëâ ‚ÄúWith AI coding assistants, rapid engineering has become possible in a way that wasn‚Äôt possible before, so the speed of engineering is going up rapidly and the (engineering) cost is also going down very fast.‚Äù

But there's a difference.

Such speed gains heavily depend on the type of application being developed:

‚Ä¢ For prototypes ‚Üí 10x faster!
‚Ä¢ For production software ‚Üí 30‚Äì50% faster?

Why?

Because standalone prototypes have:

1. Far less integration with legacy systems, and¬†¬†
2. Much lower requirements for reliability, scalability, and security.

What does this mean?

‚Ä¢ For entrepreneurs ‚Üí You can now build (with AI) 10x more prototypes to see what works.
‚Ä¢ For dev employees ‚Üí You should focus on working directly with production systems.
‚Ä¢ For everyone ‚Üí You can now move fast while being responsible.

posts.text:
Watched Fran√ßois Collet's talk: "How We Get to AGI" tonight with great interest. He presented unique insights based on years of research creating scientific benchmarks for measuring AI‚Äôs intelligence.

My takeaway:

"As long as we can easily come out with tasks that are easy for humans, but that AI can‚Äôt figure out, we don‚Äôt have AGI yet."

My notes:

üîπ Fluid intelligence:
‚§∑¬†It doesn‚Äôt emerge from pretraining and scaling GPT models.

üîπ Test-Time Adaptation (TTA):
‚§∑¬†It has dramatically improved model capabilities, but it‚Äôs still not AGI.

üîπ What is intelligence, anyway? 
‚§∑¬†Intelligence is a process, not to be confused with "skill", which is the output of that process. So, intelligence is the ability to deal with new situations.

üîπ What is AGI, then?
‚§∑¬†We shouldn‚Äôt define AGI as a system that can perform 80% of economically valuable tasks. Instead, true AGI would be a system that can learn new skills efficiently and solve previously unseen problems.

In the end, Collet shares his current work on building a new kind of AI model capable of extrapolating NEW solutions using a ‚Äúlibrary‚Äù of previously discovered abstractions.

In his view, the ultimate goal of AGI isn‚Äôt automation. It‚Äôs to accelerate scientific progress.

Overall, a remarkable talk by a brilliant scientist.

* I personally don‚Äôt believe Collet's suite of interactive video games is the best way for determining whether we've reached AGI.

My favorite slide üëá

posts.text:
The media is now buzzing about Meta's Superintelligence Labs and Zuckerberg‚Äôs "secret list‚Äù of elite #AI PhDs, reportedly receiving offers around $100M.

What‚Äôs interesting to me: 
‚§∑ Never before have a handful of PhD researchers been valued so highly. For comparison, $100M is roughly twice NBA superstar LeBron James‚Äôs base salary in 2025.

But...

‚Üí¬†How much is that price tag in the grand scheme of things?
‚Üí¬†How does anyone could measure the true value of a human brain?

As a PhD graduate, let me share 5 thoughts on this:

1Ô∏è‚É£ We now have incredibly powerful AI models, but building them depends on a very small circle of top-tier minds (now in their 30s) who were working in obscure, undervalued research areas just a few years ago.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Meta isn‚Äôt simply paying for researchers, it‚Äôs paying for battle-tested, experimental experience in building and deploying LLMs at scale.

3Ô∏è‚É£ For Meta and other companies of similar size, $100M is just a fraction of what‚Äôs invested in AI infrastructure, such as GPU data centers.

4Ô∏è‚É£ We still don‚Äôt know whether this talent race will drive new breakthroughs or merely concentrate intellectual power in a few corporate labs.

5Ô∏è‚É£ This isn‚Äôt good news for the traditional academic system. PhD graduates deserve high pay, top talent eill flood into Big Tech, chasing billions instead of papers and teaching.

Either way, what a time to be fitting tensors and orchestrating agents! 

I wish I had done my PhD in NLP a decade ago :/

Once again, the future proves unpredictable üîÆ

posts.text:
Data munging has a couple of levels to it ‚Üì

Level 1 - Data Fits in Memory
‚§∑¬† Store data locally
‚§∑¬† Use Pandas/Polars for ETL
‚§∑¬† Train models with scikit-learn, TensorFlow, or PyTorch

Level 2 - Distributed Production Systems
‚§∑¬† Process live or streaming data
‚§∑¬† Build distributed pipelines using PySpark/Dask
‚§∑¬† Deploy models that retrain in batches

As a rule of thumb:

üëâ If your data fits in your laptop‚Äôs RAM, you're still playing at Level 1.

The real world runs on logs, events, clickstreams, APIs, terabytes, and SLAs. It‚Äôs fragmented, noisy, and constantly in constant motion.

However, most data scientists don‚Äôt actually work with real-world data. Bridging the gap between development and production requires a shift in mindset and tooling.

So, how to level up?

‚úÖ Learn distributed computing:
‚§∑¬† Use PySpark, Dask, or SQL engines like BigQuery
‚§∑¬† Operate with scale as the default assumption

‚úÖ Think like an engineer:
‚§∑¬† Design DAGs. Build pipelines. Automate every step
‚§∑¬† Treat the model as just one component in a larger system

‚úÖ Go beyond notebooks:
‚§∑¬† Dockerize workflows. Orchestrate with Airflow or Prefect
‚§∑¬† Integrate with CI/CD pipelines and monitoring

Again, true impact starts when we reach production. When our ML models meet the live, messy, massive, beautiful chaos of the real world.

Let‚Äôs plug them in üîå

posted_at.relative: 1 month ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
I've watched the recent talk ‚ÄúSoftware in The Era of AI‚Äù by Andrej Karpathy at Y Combinator many times now.

With 1M+ views on YT, it‚Äôs one of the best #AI talks I‚Äôve seen for a general audience.

In ~40 minutes, Andrej distills the current trajectory of AI in a way that‚Äôs clear, engaging, and inspiring.

I've recommended it to many friends, and now I find myself asking:
‚§∑¬†What makes this talk exceptional?
‚§∑¬†What can we learn from the speaker?

Here‚Äôs what I think makes it superb:
‚úì He seems genuinely excited about the topic, positive, and has open body language.
‚úì He shares personal work along the way (tweets, posts, photos, and anecdotes), building trust and authenticity.
‚úì He speaks in 1st person, sharing opinions and reflections (‚ÄúI think‚Ä¶‚Äù), which makes it feel personal.
‚úì He uses analogies and real-world examples constantly, e.g., when calling LLMs a new kind of OS.
‚úì He structures his talk into clear sections, recapping each one to reinforce key ideas.
‚úì His slides alternate between big, bold visuals and simple, centered headlines.
‚úì Most importantly, his tone stays hopeful throughout. Even when discussing limitations, he keeps the vibe optimistic.

Below is a more detailed breakdown of his flow ‚Üì

Intro:
‚Ä¢ Begins with enthusiasm and gratitude for being there.
‚Ä¢ Remarks on the title and explains why the topic matters.
‚Ä¢ Frames the big question: Why is software changing so fast?
‚Ä¢ Provides a historical perspective: Software 1.0 ‚Üí 2.0 ‚Üí 3.0.
‚Ä¢ Uses concrete examples to highlight his key observation.

Part 1: Software Evolution
‚Ä¢ Quotes Andrew Ng: AI is the new electricity.
‚Ä¢ Explains the analogy with real-life examples (e.g., factories ‚Üí software).
‚Ä¢ Adds his twist: "LLMs are like a new OS."
‚Ä¢ Introduces a counterintuitive idea: We have a new magical computer helping us boil eggs.
‚Ä¢ Summarizes Part 1 with bullet points.

Part 2: The Psychology of LLMs
‚Ä¢ Dives a bit into the internals of LLMs (transformers).
‚Ä¢ Acknowledges their current limitations.
‚Ä¢ Recommends sci-fi movies as a gift to the audience.
‚Ä¢ Summarizes Part 2 with images.

Part 3: New Opportunities
‚Ä¢ Offers a new abstraction: LLMs as the GUIs for machine intelligence.
‚Ä¢ Gives real examples of current successes (e.g., Cursor).
‚Ä¢ Poses the big question: What will future apps look like?
‚Ä¢ Weaves analogies and personal stories (how he uses LLMs, how he ‚Äúkeeps AI on a leash,‚Äù his first Waymo ride, etc).
‚Ä¢ Shows an emotional video of kids vibe coding (going emotional with a hopeful vision).
‚Ä¢ Ends Part 3 with his vibe-coded app experiments and areas still unexplored (this opens up for the next final section)

Part 4: Building for Agents
‚Ä¢ Makes a bold prediction: We‚Äôre entering a new era of digital ‚Äúagents.‚Äù
‚Ä¢ Imagines future human‚ÄìAI interaction.
‚Ä¢ Introduces upcoming tools and possibilities.

Final Summary:
‚Ä¢ Displays a collage of key slides tying everything together into a single storyline.

Overall, an extremely well-packaged talk ‚ú®
Should we try to replicate this framework?

posts.text:
There was a time when I believed I just needed to push myself harder. Grind longer. Power through the fatigue.

All I needed, I thought, was ‚Äújust one more research paper,‚Äù ‚Äújust one more OSS project,‚Äù ‚Äújust one more thing to prove to myself,‚Äù and so on‚Ä¶

This kind of self-pressure often drained me, but I was younger and could afford the late nights.

Today, I need to be more mindful of my capacity.

I‚Äôve learned that willpower isn‚Äôt an infinite resource, and that the best long-term strategy is to dose it wisely.

Motivation doesn‚Äôt fail because we‚Äôre weak. It fails because it runs out. 

Just like a muscle, our willpower gets depleted after use, and pretending it doesn‚Äôt only makes the crash harder.

And if you feel like me, most of the time the problem isn‚Äôt actually depletion, it‚Äôs refusing to refuel.

Energy is a limited resource that can easily be drained.

Looking into it, I found a 2008 study that showed people who rested just 10 minutes between demanding tasks recovered completely, while others stayed depleted.

So the next time you can‚Äôt focus, procrastinate, or lose control, don‚Äôt shame yourself. 

Your tank could be empty. What you need isn‚Äôt more discipline. You need a break that actually refuels you.

Relaxing isn‚Äôt the same as cheering up. It‚Äôs not about just ‚Äúfeeling good‚Äù, it‚Äôs about slowing down. 

Stop thinking
No cellphone
Quiet
Stillness
Doing nothing on purpose

So, I‚Äôve stopped blaming myself when I‚Äôm drained.

Every time I‚Äôm exhausted, I tell myself:¬†‚ÄúRunning on empty doesn‚Äôt make you strong, it actually makes you stuck.‚Äù

You‚Äôll never hit rock bottom again if you learn to pause before the crash üßò

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 1 month ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
The real risk with AI is not that it sometimes produces wrong outputs. It‚Äôs that we still don‚Äôt know when (or where) it will.

In 2023, researchers from Harvard University, MIT Professional Education, The Wharton School, and Boston Consulting Group (BCG) ran experiments with 758 consultants using GPT‚Äë4 and identified an invisible boundary.

They called it the "Jagged Frontier". The inability of LLMs to deal the same way with tasks with the same level of complexity for a human. 

What did they found?

When tasks matched GPT‚Äë4‚Äôs strengths:
‚úÖ +40% in quality, +25% faster execution, +12% more output

But when tasks didn‚Äôt:
‚ùå A 19% drop in efficiency 

Fair enough :/ But what's the real issue?

The problem is that most people couldn‚Äôt tell when they‚Äôd crossed the line:

üëâ ‚ÄúOn some tasks AI is immensely powerful, and on others it fails completely or subtly. And unless you use AI a lot, you won‚Äôt know which is which.‚Äù

Okay, that was 2 years ago. Today‚Ä¶

AI systems are adapting: adding guardrails, evals, decision triggers, and human oversight.

The frontier is beginning to blur, not because LLMs are flawless, but because our systems for working with them are getting better.

We‚Äôre entering a new agentic phase by:

‚úì Mapping workflows ‚Üí¬†e.g., aligning AI strengths with task complexity
‚úì Building guardrails ‚Üí¬†e.g., audit trails, explainable outputs, confidence thresholds
‚úì Upskilling humans ‚Üí¬†e.g., at prompt design, uncertainty detection, human-in-the-loop orchestration

I believe there is great potential in having models that know when to pause, ask, and let humans decide, completely flattering the line. 

Ask yourself:
Where are the jagged edges in your current workflow?

Tbh, it's getting harder for me to figure this one out üòÑ

posts.text:
Attended my first Google Cloud Summit Nordics at Avicii Arena in Stockholm, this time was all about ü§ñ ‚à© ‚òÅÔ∏è. Below are my thoughts from what I saw there ‚Üì

1Ô∏è‚É£ The cloud giants have gone all-in on AI.

Rapid customer acquisition and marketing are often high priorities in the early stages of disruptive technologies. The race is on. Google, Microsoft, and Amazon are aggressively positioning their clouds as AI-first platforms. These cloud providers have the competitive advantage of already having the necessary infrastructure to create AI-native cloud services. For them, it‚Äôs a numbers game üí∏

2Ô∏è‚É£ Yet, no mind-blowing innovation on the sight.

With Gemini 2.5 Pro, one can write JavaScript frontend, Java backend, and Terraform IaC in natural language without leaving the platform. It can now feed all your company data into its context window and answer questions about it. But we already knew it would be just a matter of time before this happened. The question is: what else? Personally, I would like to see new use cases. For example, a new type of AI-powered product integrated in a way that I could really use in my daily life, beyond the well-known chatbot-styled UI (maybe an AI-native hardware device would be interesting) üïπÔ∏è

3Ô∏è‚É£ For devs, AI is a double-edged productivity boost. 

On-cloud AI code assistants will change how we create and deploy apps. There‚Äôs truly no going back to handwriting code from scratch anymore. I wonder if there is any chance for local AI-powered IDEs when these cloud providers have all the context integrated... I don‚Äôt know, but for the time being, AI is being sold as the perfect way to ‚Äúexperiment quickly, build agentic experiences, shift down, use AI assistance, and become wildly more productive,‚Äù hmm üôÑ 

My last takeaway: Move faster. Build smarter. Offload to an AI the grunt work. Ship on the cloud like never before. Tomorrow, we don‚Äôt know.

Yesterday, I participated in the Google Cloud AI Hackathon, held to celebrate the launch of its cloud region in Sweden. I tried vibe-coding a Firebase app without writing a single LoC myself. Below are 7 thoughts that crossed my mind during the day ‚Üì

1Ô∏è‚É£ Everyone should learn how to use AI to build software. I mean EVERYONE, no excuses. If you haven‚Äôt tried yet‚Ä¶ what are you waiting for?

2Ô∏è‚É£ The best (and probably only) way to understand AI‚Äôs impact on software development is by playing with it and trying as many tools as you can. I guess you already know the benefits, limits, and ideal use cases of the most popular ones‚Ä¶ do you?

3Ô∏è‚É£ Having access to an AI-driven cloud ecosystem speeds things up a lot. You can build a full working prototype from (clear) idea to deployment in a few hours just by prompting Gemini 2.5. It is capable of orchestrating the cloud-native components like a boss! This makes me wonder... will app development outside agentic private clouds soon feel obsolete?

4Ô∏è‚É£ Most of the participants were quite young. I‚Äôd estimate the average age was under 30, and some winners weren‚Äôt even developers. Are more seasoned professional devs missing the AI r/evolution?

5Ô∏è‚É£ Seeing these tools in action, and how insanely fast you can build with them, made me question everything. Do traditional dev practices, like SCRUM, do they even make sense anymore? Can we truly be ‚ÄúAI native‚Äù if we keep using workflows designed to harness lazy humans?

6Ô∏è‚É£ One of the biggest mindset shifts I had was this: you don‚Äôt need to know everything to start building. With the right AI tools, you can learn while doing. Skipping hours of tutorials and docs. Does it even make sense to read tutorials anymore?

7Ô∏è‚É£ Hackathons are such a great way to level up, connect with energetic folks, and get a front-row seat to the future. Seems like the new best way to get people involved, so there's a big opportunity there for everyone: Hackathons are the Bootcamps v2.0! 

Anyway, I‚Äôm thrilled #Sweden just became a Google Cloud hub in the Nordics! üá∏üá™üöÄ‚òÅÔ∏è

I had a great time today attending the Open Infra Forum in Stockholm, a big event with a large community celebrating its 10th anniversary.

Open infrastructure is a matter of digital sovereignty, and everyone from tech professionals to policymakers should understand its importance.

Some thought-provoking questions that stuck with me:

üî• If the cloud were turned off in one minute, would your company still function?
üî• Would the Swedish public sector still operate?
üî• What if a service you rely on gets deprecated in a month?
üî• What if the price suddenly spikes, could you migrate away?
üî• What if there‚Äôs no cloud for you?
üî• Are you even able to breathe?

So here‚Äôs the core message:

üí¶ Digital independence and knowledge are key.
üí¶ Your data belongs to you, and no one else.
üí¶ If the cloud goes down, the self-hoster becomes king.
üí¶ If the internet goes down, the self-hoster is the prince.

As a üéÅ, our Swedish legend Daniel Stenberg shared his experiences as creator and lifelong maintainer of #cURL (first release was in 1996). Hearing how cURL quietly conquered the world, alongside the rise of open-source, was a real delight.

BTW, Daniel wrote a book capturing everything he knows about running and maintaining open-source projects for nearly three decades:
‚§∑ https://un.curl.dev/

$ curl ifconfig.me

I'm all in on AI, but there are some uncomfortable echoes from the past that I can‚Äôt ignore.

Do you still remember the blockchain ‚Äúrevolution‚Äù 5 years ago?
I do, and it's clear that it never happened.

Billions were poured in üí∞
Bold promises about a economic freedom and a new Web3 were made.
But half a decade later, most companies walked away from the idea.

Disclaimer: I truly believed in blockchain and descentralized finance, I even ran my own Ethereum nodes and wrote research papers about it!

Now, I look around...
And sometimes it feels like I‚Äôm hearing the same kind of hype all over again.

‚ÄúWe're becoming an AI-first company.‚Äù
That‚Äôs the new memo trend from CEOs at big tech companies.

But the latest AI Index 2025 Report tells a different story:

‚Ü≥ ‚ÄúSo far, most companies are seeing less than 5% revenue growth from their AI investments.‚Äù 

After all the pitches, all the funding, and all the models. 
It looks like the actual returns haven‚Äôt arrived yet.
Most are waiting for that big ROI.

Still, no one wants to hit the brakes.

So, here‚Äôs what I think:

AI tech isn‚Äôt failing.
It‚Äôs just not magic.
Yet, it's very easy to buy such promises.

You don‚Äôt transform a company with a tool.
You do it with vision.
With iteration.
And above all, with the joined efforts of great human talents.

So please, let‚Äôs stop chasing headlines.
Let‚Äôs build quietly, strategically.
Because we‚Äôre not going to reinvent society in a few quarters.
It‚Äôll take years.

If you're committed for the long haul, you‚Äôre exactly where you need to be.

And hopefully, this time, we won't end up with just more speculation and memecoins ü™ô

Pandas is dead. Long live Polars.

And I know, it hurts... 
I‚Äôve used Pandas for years. But after trying Polars, there‚Äôs no turning back.

Why?

Because Polars is blazing fast.
It‚Äôs built in Rust ü¶Ä and powered by Apache Arrow üèπ, giving it an edge that Pandas can‚Äôt match.

Polars optimizes operations.
Like Spark, it builds an execution graph and runs it only when needed, thanks to its lazy evaluation mechanism.

Anyway, I was never comfortable with Pandas' syntax.
Pandas‚Äô is imperative, Polars embraces a functional style ‚Üí¬†clean, expressive, and reminiscent of R‚Äôs tidyverse (yep, I was an R fanboy before Python took over data-verse).

But here‚Äôs what sealed the deal for me to use Polars:

üîπTransformations return new objects by default, no side effects, no surprises.
üîπIt runs multi-threaded, utilizing every core without me lifting a finger.
üîπIt‚Äôs energy efficient, researchers recommend it over Pandas for large datasets.

Experiments from an EASE 2024 paper show clear results:

‚ÄúPolars dramatically reduces execution time and energy use, especially on large Data Analysis Tasks (DATs).‚Äù
 
Full paper here: https://lnkd.in/dR2aeh-d

If you‚Äôre still clinging to Pandas, ask yourself:

Why settle for slow, clunky libraries in a world that demands speed, clarity, and efficiency?

Choose wisely, my friend üêª‚Äç‚ùÑÔ∏è

GitHub just released a dataset to compare OSS collaborations between global economies, and it confirms something I‚Äôve long suspected:

The EU is the world‚Äôs OSS workforce, whereas the US is the world‚Äôs OSS headquarter and largest beneficiary. 

The inbound/outbound collaborator graphs make it clear üëá

üì• Inbound ‚Üí Who Receives?

The US sees a huge inflow. Developers worldwide contribute to US-owned repos. In contrast, the EU gets far fewer inbound contributions than it sends out.

üì§ Outbound ‚Üí Who Gives?

The EU leads in outbound activity. EU devs contribute heavily to projects outside the region. The US contributes far less by comparison.

‚öñÔ∏è The imbalance is huge, meaning:

‚Ü≥¬†OSS gravity (forks, issues, PRs, and visibility) pulls toward the US, whereas EU projects don‚Äôt attract the same global attention.
‚Ü≥¬†The EU is a code contributor, not a code destination.
‚Ü≥¬†For the US, this leads to better sustainability, faster innovation, and more influence. 
‚Ü≥¬†For the EU, it‚Äôs a strategic vulnerability, relying on OSS platforms it doesn‚Äôt control.
‚Ü≥¬†Key libraries and infrastructure are US-based, eroding EU digital sovereignty.
‚Ü≥¬†EU devs are working for free on US projects, efforts without royalties.

This tech power imbalance is worth fixing.

üéØ Here‚Äôre three ways to start changing it:

1. The EU should invest more on local OSS (tools, libraries, and specially AI frameworks).
2. The EU should host and protect key projects within EU jurisdictions.
3. The EU should create OSS alliances and Foundations, building contributor communities across EU countries. 

On my view, this obviously isn‚Äôt a lack of talent. It‚Äôs a failure of platform and resources' ownership.

You build it üíª. You run it ‚ö°Ô∏è. You earn from it üí∞. That‚Äôs how it should be.

Source: https://lnkd.in/dJRnE7Va

P.S. The width of each stream in the graphs below represents the volume of git pushes and PRs from one economy to others. Wider = more collaboration flow. China (in blue), has similar inbound/outbound margins.

posted_at.relative: 3 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
ML projects don‚Äôt fail because models are wrong, they fail because the training data is unreliable.

In my experience, unreliable data pipelines are the fastest way to destroy trust in our work.

That‚Äôs why determinism and idempotence in data transformation pipelines aren‚Äôt ‚Äúnice-to-haves.‚Äù They‚Äôre our first line of defense!

Determinism:
‚Ü≥ same input data, same output - every single time.

Idempotence:
‚Ü≥ run the same operation once or 100x - result doesn‚Äôt change.

So, how to get both of them?

Start here:

‚úÖ Make every transformation deterministic
‚Üí No randomness without fixed seeds
‚Üí No reliance on timestamps or implicit environment state
‚Üí No third-party data without versioning

‚úÖ Make every job idempotent
‚Üí Safe to re-run without side effects
‚Üí Always overwrite outputs, never append blindly
‚Üí Use unique, content-based identifiers for deduplication

‚úÖ Test like credibility depends on it (because it does)
‚Üí Compare outputs over time
‚Üí Add pipeline-level regression tests
‚Üí Monitor for unexpected failures

Determinism + Idempotence = No+üëª

posts.text:
Once upon a time‚Ä¶ we actually used to read tech books. Do you remember?

Those days were truly amazing!

It's incredibly that we had the time (and the patience) to go over books from start to finish.

Whenever I wanted to learn something new, I‚Äôd just grab a good one from a reputable source and start from scratch.

A good thing I remember is that most books were created to teach "why" things worked, not just "how." Step by step. Concept by concept.

We kept them on our shelves and the chapters in our minds, like mental maps we could revisit anytime.

But today?

‚Ü≥ Tech moves so fast that by the time you finish a book, it might already be outdated.

Why?

‚Ü≥ Because the levels of abstraction keep climbing. Everything is built on top of frameworks, libraries, or APIs that evolve overnight.

And also now, with #LLMs, we just ask for what we need, right when we need it. No need to store the sources anymore.

Still‚Ä¶ I miss the feeling of quietly reading for the sake of it.

The feeling of having no pressure, no rush to build something asap.

Just learning for fun... did it actually exist?

Reading books has become a luxury. That's it.

A luxury for people who have the most valuable resource on earth: time.

If you‚Äôre one of them, enjoy üìñ, because many of us have already succumbed to the LLMs ü§ñ

P.S. Yes, there are still timeless classics every dev should read, you should know the ones ;)

posted_at.relative: 3 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
Have you ever had that awkward moment, just after jumping into a new large codebase, when you find everything wild and chaotic?

I know, it‚Äôs hard to avoid thinking: ‚ÄúThis is a mess. How could anyone maintain this stuff?‚Äù

If you‚Äôve been into software long enough, I‚Äôm 100% sure you‚Äôve had this kind of feeling.

But over time, I‚Äôve learned something:

‚Ü≥ When really complex systems work for real customers, even if they work imperfectly, that‚Äôs not something to take lightly.

The very fact that it has worked and survived the test of time is a huge achievement!

Because complex systems are always messy from the inside out.

SIDE NOTE: You know what I mean, the complexity of software is such a fascinating thing, isn‚Äôt it? üòÅ

This complexity is the price we pay for solving real problems at scale.

There‚Äôs no way to escape from it.

We don‚Äôt eliminate complexity, we just move it around and hide it with abstractions. 

That‚Äôs why I hesitate before touching legacy code that has quietly done its job for years.

Now I only change old, battle-proven code when I absolutely must. Seriously.

If you're in doubt, remember Chesterton‚Äôs Fence: 

‚Ü≥ ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tear down a fence until you understand why it was built.‚Äù

In other words: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt change what you don‚Äôt understand!‚Äù

I know it's hard this days, with #AI tools, it‚Äôs easier than ever to refactor or rewrite code. The bar to start making changes has lowered down significantly. But there‚Äôs a danger in how quickly we forget why something exists. For example, AI doesn‚Äôt know that a function was built around a legal constraint, a performance hack, or a hard-learned production failure.

Many disasters in software don‚Äôt come from bad intentions. They come from lack of context and/or ignoring history.

New leaders often arrive, find things ‚Äúuseless‚Äù or ‚Äúbroken,‚Äù and want to delete or change them without appreciating the journey it took other devs to get there.

So when entering into a new codebase, respect wildlife like a nice guest in your neighbor's house. Because we won‚Äôt be able to fully grasp the intricacies of an ecosystem at the first glance, and that‚Äôs why we tread lightly.

Let me said it again, we should stop pretending complexity can be removed. I've seen so many failed attempts into this direction... I can't count.

Let‚Äôs accept complexity, that‚Äôs all. 

Good engineers make sure they understand the past before trying to mess around with the present.

Let‚Äôs respect wildlife, for our own survival! üêü

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 4 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
Many of us once read TAOCP and believed that coding and algorithms were a form of art that couldn‚Äôt be automated.

But we were wrong.

What I once saw as a unique human craft is now the next target for assembly line automation.

Turns out that programming is just advanced pattern-matching, and #LLMs are extremely good at it.

#AI doesn‚Äôt just generate code that runs, it‚Äôs already getting better than most human developers when looking at code quality.

But I‚Äôm not disillusioned about the future of software engineering, I‚Äôm just waking up to the shift‚Ä¶

Because this isn‚Äôt just another bump in abstraction, like when we moved from assembly to higher-level PLs, I think it‚Äôs a paradigm shift.

We‚Äôre no longer writing most code from scratch, and if you still see yourself as a ‚Äúcode writer,‚Äù you‚Äôll be left behind.

I believe the true winners in this new era will be those who understand how software should work, not just how to ‚Äúmake it work once.‚Äù

Because writing code isn‚Äôt the hard part anymore. That problem has been effectively solved, much like how machine translation was solved with Transformers.

Now, the real challenge is:
‚Üí Know what to build.
‚Üí Know how it should work.
‚Üí Know how to make it evolve.

For example, I can prompt an LLM to write code that ingests messages from a Kafka topic and stores them in a PostgreSQL DB.

But I still need to:
‚Üí Handle message deduplication and idempotency.
‚Üí Implement retries with exponential backoff on database failures.
‚Üí Design the storage schema to accommodate evolving message formats.

Clear thinking about design, data, performance, and maintenance is becoming the most valuable skill in tech.

So no, I‚Äôm not walking away from code.

I‚Äôm doubling down on software design, distributed systems, and everything that makes software robust, maintainable, and scalable.

Cause if we know what we're doing, AI won't replace us, it'll just make us 100x more valuable.

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 4 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
I love knobs, buttons, and PBT keycaps.
There‚Äôs something deeply satisfying about that tactile feedback, ... like my fingers are really feeling the machines. 

But two decades ago, we started replacing our lovely physical UX by something else (thanks, Apple for the iPhone). 
Everything shifted to flat, glowing digital keyboards in the name of "productivity," "more features," and "more screen space."

Now these screens are everywhere, even where it doesn't make any sense.
Touchscreens on fridges, on my front door, on cars (thanks, Tesla). 
Even TVs have on-screen keyboards?!

Oh, I have to mention my Samsung TV here.
It forces me to search using a remote with no physical letters that only moves in four directions‚Ä¶ typing one letter at a time ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

But now #AI has arrived, finally.
#LLMs promise to change everything.
And the industry now wants to replace the digital keyboard with voice.

But sure, we‚Äôve heard this before: Siri, Alexa, Google Home. Do you remember?
They never really took off.

So is natural language finally the future of UX?

Honestly‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt think so.

Why?

Because it's inefficient, limited, and inconvenient.

‚Üí¬†It‚Äôs inefficient because we think at thousands of words per minute but can only speak ~150. And unlike typing, you can‚Äôt easily go back and edit your words when speaking. That makes natural language interactions slow, error-prone, and frustrating.

‚Üí¬†It‚Äôs limited because it's lossy and ambiguous. Structured commands are clear. Language is fuzzy. You say one thing, the machine hears another. And you enter a cycle of clarifications.

‚Üí¬†It‚Äôs inconvenient because saying ‚ÄúOpen a new tab‚Äù out loud when ‚åòT does it instantly is nonsense. Not to mention that this doesn't work in public spaces. 

So no, #LLMs won‚Äôt replace the mouse and keyboard.
It doesn't matter how good the models will get.

When we‚Äôll ditch them?
If you ask me, I think that'll happen when #AI can finally read our thoughts.

But that‚Äôs another story.

For now, I‚Äôll keep enjoying the satisfying clack clack of my hand-modded mechanical keyboard ‚å®Ô∏è

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 4 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
Let me tell you a quick story about programming, chess, and what's been wrong with coding interviews for decades:

In my 1st year of grad school, I heard about programming contests. They sounded exciting, but I didn‚Äôt solved any problem (I didn't know how to code in 2009).

By 2nd year, I jumped in, competed in a local ACM-ICPC tournament and got hooked.

Next year, I was solving problem after problem on online judges (got 1,000+ correct submissions) and went to the regionals. It felt like leveling up in a video game.

But something changed.

The deeper I went, the more I realized: this wasn‚Äôt fun anymore. It was like ches: to really excel, you have to dedicate your life to it (I love chess, btw). 

That killed the joy.

So I stepped away.

Years later, I entered the job market, and boom! Coding interviews (especially in big tech) were all about solving those kinds of ADA problems live, under extreme pressure.

It felt familiar. Too familiar‚Ä¶

But in this case there's a huge problem:

Solving algorithm puzzles in 45 mins has nothing to do with writing clean, maintainable software in the real world.

Worse, the system is really broken:

‚Ü≥ It rewards people who‚Äôve memorized patterns, not those who solve real problems.
‚Ü≥ It filters out brilliant engineers who haven‚Äôt ‚ÄúLeetcoded enough.‚Äù
‚Ü≥ It creates a test that‚Äôs easy to fail.

I understand that this test style is scalable, but I've seen senior engineers with PhDs and successful OSS projects spending weeks practicing LeetCode problems just to get past the first interview screen.

Putting that much energy into riddles wasn‚Äôt that bad 20 years ago. But the world has changed a lot since then.

Today‚Äôs #LLMs can solve most ACM-ICPC problems in seconds.

I don't really see how this could be a good way to test the value of professionals.

Today I read about undetectable apps that feeds GPT-powered answers during LeetCode-style online interviews, like the one created by Roy Lee.

So the system will collapse under its own weight (at least for its online mode). But honestly... I'm happy about it.

It‚Äôs finally time to kill programming-contest-style interviews for good.

So what should we do instead?

Here are some alternatives that I believe actually reflect real skills:

‚Ü≥ Give a real-world business problem. Ask the candidate to design and implement a solution from scratch. Discuss trade-offs, architecture, and impact.
‚Ü≥ Show messy, buggy, insecure code. Ask what‚Äôs wrong, what‚Äôs risky, and how they‚Äôd fix it.
‚Ü≥ Give raw data. Ask them to build something that adds or creates business value.

The whole point should be to simulate the real job. Because the real job lives in the real world. And in the real world, there is #AI, whether we want it or not.

So, let‚Äôs stop testing people on fantasy skills.

If you have a different idea, let me know üôÇ

posts.text:
How can a large company like SEB foster innovation?

That was the question that my colleague Georg Schuppe addressed yesterday in the session: ‚ÄúSEBx: Innovate Beyond the Future.‚Äù

I  very much agree with his vision: We need to be OK with trying new things and failing. 

The blockers to innovation are common to all big companies:
‚Ü≥ Employees drowning in repetitive tasks.
‚Ü≥ Managers too busy to make it a priority.
‚Ü≥ Data locked behind inaccessible databases.
‚Ü≥ Brilliant ideas crushed by silence, slow decisions, or KPIs.

The result?
‚Ü≥ Stagnation wrapped in legacy systems.
‚Ü≥ Big dreams with no budget.
‚Ü≥ ‚ÄúAgile‚Äù in name only.

So how to break it out?

I think we need to understand that innovation isn‚Äôt a fuzzy buzzword.

It‚Äôs a system!

And systems must scale if designed correctly. 

McKinsey & Company describes innovation based on three horizons:

1. Core (Incremental change):
‚Ü≥ Defend and extend what already works.
‚Ü≥ For example, to create internal tools, automate existing processes, or make small improvements.

2. Emerging (Disruptive change):
‚Ü≥ Build what‚Äôs next.
‚Ü≥ For example, SEB Embedded came from the idea of banking as a service, which wasn‚Äôt such a cool idea 10 years ago, it was a bet that paid off.

3. Future (Transformational change):
‚Ü≥ Invent the unthinkable.
‚Ü≥ For example, 5 years ago, a superintelligent AI assistant in your pocket felt like sci-fi, today it is transforming multiple industries. 

So...

To unlock Core innovation:
‚Ü≥ Give people time and basic resources.
‚Ü≥ Let them fix what‚Äôs broken in their daily work.
‚Ü≥ And reward those who dare to care.

To foster Emerging innovation:
‚Ü≥ Create a multidisciplinary ecosystem of experts.
‚Ü≥ Give them support from the business to prototype, test, and implement innovative concepts swiftly and effectively.
‚Ü≥ Let them move fast, fail publicly, and try again.

To pursue Future innovation:
‚Ü≥ Fund the long game.
‚Ü≥ Protect wild ideas from quarterly goals.
‚Ü≥ Empower your visionaries, not only to deliver, but also to dream.

Because‚Ä¶

The future doesn‚Äôt wait for a greenlight from leadership. It arrives, whether you‚Äôre ready or not.

So here's a question for you:

Does your company has built an innovation system? 

If yes, üëè

posts.text:
I‚Äôve heard a lot of hype about the new ChatGPT-4o image generation model, so I decided to test it with one simple task:

"To remove the green background from an uploaded close-up picture of mine and replace it with a pure black background."

That‚Äôs it. No fancy edits. Just background removal.

I tried multiple prompts. Tweaked the wording. Iterated many times on the pictures asking to only change the background, and repeated the process.

Every result failed.

Why?

Because the generated images didn‚Äôt look like me.

The differences were subtle: slightly off eyes, jawline, weird teeth, or unreal skin tone. Yet, they were enough to break the illusion (down below is the best result I got üëá).

Here‚Äôs the problem: the model has never seen me before.

Unless you‚Äôre a public figure, an actor, a politician, or someone with a massive online presence (i.e., online pictures) these models can only guess.

So, the current limitations of current AI models aren't the models themselves. It‚Äôs the training data!

So, the next time you deploy a #GenAI solution in production, remember this:

Without the right data, even the smartest model could fly blind üôà

Some words matter more than we think. According to IEEE, the language we use in our publications, presentations, and meetings may carry unintended harm and needs to evolve.

Here are a few examples from their Inclusive Language Guide (2025):

‚Ä¢ Blacklist ‚Üí Block list
‚Ä¢¬†Whitelist ‚Üí Access list
‚Ä¢ Black box ‚Üí Closed box
‚Ä¢ White box ‚Üí Glass box
‚Ä¢ Caretaker ‚Üí Caregiver
‚Ä¢ Master/Slave ‚Üí Primary/Secondary
‚Ä¢ Unmanned vehicles ‚Üí Autonomous vehicles

It won't be easy for me to change these terms, especially when speaking off the cuff.

However, I understand that while some may see them as harmless metaphors, others hear racist, ableist, or sexist undertones that have quietly lingered in our shared vocabulary.

These connotations have no place in a professional community anymore.

To build truly inclusive systems, we must start with inclusive language.

Because:

üß† Better language ‚Üí Better thinking
ü§ù Better thinking ‚Üí Better inclusion
üåç Better inclusion ‚Üí Better innovation

Let‚Äôs stop assuming our words are harmless just because they‚Äôre common.

In the coming years, human developers and AI tools will form a powerful partnership, but many challenges still lie ahead.

Here are some examples:

‚Üí Requirements Engineering: AI must accurately grasp user needs without gaps.
‚Üí Software Design: AI suggestions must be clear, trustworthy, and easy to integrate.
‚Üí Code Generation: AI code must be correct, secure, scalable, and energy-efficient.
‚Üí Software Testing: AI must independently create effective tests to verify its own code.
‚Üí Software Maintenance: AI must process vast amounts of external data to identify improvements, fairly and strategically.

There is no doubt that the current (and future) generation of software engineers needs to master AI tools.

However, I believe we should not abandon core software engineering principles.

"Vibe coding" without engineering judgment will inevitably undermine the quality and safety of our software systems.

And I also believe that human judgment will always be essential to critically assess AI-generated artifacts from a business perspective.

So far... AI is a productivity multiplier, not a replacement for human expertise.

For the over-optimists:
‚Ü≥ You can‚Äôt outsource judgment.
‚Ü≥ You can‚Äôt automate accountability.
‚Ü≥ You can‚Äôt change what you don‚Äôt understand.

Exciting times to be in the AI4SE field! üöÄ

P.S. Check out the paper: "The Future of AI-Driven Software Engineering", in ACM Transactions on Software Engineering and Methodology (2025).

posts.text:
I‚Äôve been building software with #Java for years, and I can say this with absolute confidence: Java is still one of the smartest career bets a developer can make.

Why?

Because Java isn‚Äôt going anywhere.

Yet people still say it‚Äôs outdated. Dusty. Too verbose. Too ‚Äúenterprisey.‚Äù

Wrong.

Java quietly powers much of the real world.
From the Spotify app on your phone to backend systems moving trillions of financial transactions, Java is there. Relentless. Invisible. Indispensable.

It runs Android, Inc. Netflix. LinkedIn. Minecraft. Most banks. Many governments.
It‚Äôs everywhere.

Why?

Because Java works!
It‚Äôs stable. Fast. Secure. Built for scale.
And with every new release, it‚Äôs getting better.

Java 23 is proof the language is only accelerating:
‚úîÔ∏è Streamlined syntax ‚Üí¬† A ‚ÄúHello, World!‚Äù now takes just a few lines of code.
‚úîÔ∏è Pattern matching for primitives ‚Üí¬†Cleaner logic with less clutter.
‚úîÔ∏è Markdown for JavaDocs ‚Üí Documentation that doesn‚Äôt make your eyes bleed.
‚úîÔ∏è Immutable records + sealed classes ‚Üí¬†Safer data structures, fewer bugs, tighter control.

What about AI?

Well, sure, #Python dominates ML/DL/AI.
But when it‚Äôs time to deployments, many real-world AI systems hum quietly on the JVM.

Take Uber‚Äôs Michelangelo platform, it uses Java to serve real-time machine learning predictions at global scale.

And with libraries and frameworks like Deeplearning4j, LangChain4J, and TensorFlow integrations, you don‚Äôt have to rebuild your systems in Python to get AI features. You just enhance what you already have.

Moreover, I think Java teaches us how to think like an engineer.
With strong types and well-established design patterns, Java encourages discipline. It‚Äôs simply harder to make a mess.

And that discipline? 

Could sometimes make a difference üçµ

posts.text:
Today, I attended the dbt Labs meetup at Solita's office in Stockholm. Here‚Äôs a key insight I took away:

The "semantic layer" is a big deal for both businesses and developers.

Johan Baltzar shared his journey as a Data Engineer in Spotify‚Äôs early days and how a deep understanding of the semantic layer played a crucial role in helping the Swedish ü¶Ñ scale from A to B (as shown in the pictures ‚á£).

What is the semantic layer? (just in case you wonder)

It‚Äôs a logical abstraction that translates raw data structures (tables, columns, schemas) into user-friendly, meaningful business terms.

For example, imagine two departments independently calculating revenue. Without a semantic layer, they could report wildly different numbers, both technically correct but confusingly inconsistent. A semantic layer ensures everyone speaks the same language from the start, providing a single, trustworthy definition for terms like "revenue".

Modern data stacks increasingly rely on semantic layers to democratize data analytics. Looker, Tableau, PowerBI.bg, and dbt Labs all offer semantic-layer capabilities, making it a hot topic in the business world!

Thanks to the organizers, I'm looking forward to the next dbt Labs event. ü•Ç

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 4 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
I don't think we need Scala anymore, the language is doomed and will disappear.

For context, Scala gained popularity only for these two reasons:

1Ô∏è‚É£ It introduced functional programming features that Java lacked at the time.

2Ô∏è‚É£ The rise of Spark, a big data framework natively written in Scala.

However, with Java‚Äôs evolution (especially since Java 8, which introduced lambdas and streams) and #Python's dominance in Data Science, Scala is no longer necessary.

The entire ML/AI ecosystem is built around Python now (NumPy, Pandas, TensorFlow, PyTorch, Scikit-learn, etc.). Furthermore, PySpark is good enough for most use cases (even Databricks heavily supports Python for ML workloads).

#Java has caught up, especially with Project Loom and its upcoming features, and any companies that previously used Scala for microservices (e.g., Twitter/X) migrated back to Java or Kotlin.

Moreover, I find Scala cumbersome to learn as a programming language. It's a mix of object-oriented and functional paradigms, and the syntax is not very intuitive (although this might be personal preference).

So, why does Scala still exist?

First, some companies (especially in finance, big data, and ad-tech) have large Scala-based Spark codebases.

Second, Python APIs (like PySpark) introduce some overhead, as Python needs to communicate with the JVM (via Py4J), which can be a bottleneck in some cases.

Finally, if you enjoy functional programming paradigms (e.g., higher-order functions, pattern matching, and monads), Scala still does them slightly better than Java.

So, I strongly believe that learning Scala isn't worth it unless your company uses Spark, of course. But if you're mainly doing AI or ML, it's better to focus on Python instead.

Finally, a question for you:

Do you still use Scala, seriously?

posted_at.relative: 4 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
I just read the latest blog post by Sean Goedecke. He wrote about what I‚Äôve been thinking about for a while: ‚ÄúThe good times in tech are over.‚Äù

I mostly agree. The job market in tech didn‚Äôt make any sense. We used to live in a Nirvana.

We all know that. For years, software engineers were untouchable: high salaries, lavish perks, job security, etc.

I personally never felt good about this situation, as I couldn‚Äôt understand how it was possible that seasoned school teachers earned less than junior software engineers.

Now we‚Äôre seeing more and more layoffs in the tech sector and definitely not the same level of security as before.

Why?

Because cheap money fueled the tech boom in the 2010s. Companies could afford anything: mass hirings, paying ridiculous salaries, and even maintaining open-source projects. Profitability didn‚Äôt matter much when money flowed the way it did.

Then interest rates spiked. Less money from investors, and the game changed.

The hard truth is thay most tech companies never really cared about open source or sustainability. They were just indulgences for devs in an era of excess.

Now, job security depends on one thing: delivering value that is connected to whatever your company cares about the most.

But there‚Äôs nothing special about this. In fact, this is how businesses operate in the real world. What was actually special was the previous job market situation.

Besides, I think the rise of AI has definitely aggravated this. And for now, it‚Äôs merely the expectation of such an impact that causes companies to hire more cautiously.

Regarding AI, here‚Äôs what I think we should focus on in order to remain appreciated:

üîπ Move efforts to where actual value is created (the specific business value is often the hardest part to automate with AI).

üîπ Embrace AI, and even better, advocate for it (such a huge and rare opportunity to become an innovator).

üîπ Accept the reality that AI isn‚Äôt going anywhere and that the good old times are over (things aren‚Äôt going to be as they used to be).

Let‚Äôs see how it goes because maybe this is just the beginning of another golden age that we still haven‚Äôt understood.

Who knows? ü§∑

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 4 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
Lately, I‚Äôve started worrying that I might be losing my ability to write complete apps from scratch.

Why?

Because the more I rely on AI coding assistants, the less I actually code myself.

Here‚Äôs how coding used to be:

Create a file ‚Üí set up imports and structure ‚Üí write functions ‚Üí add logic ‚Üí something doesn't work ‚Üí debug ‚Üí Google the issue ‚Üí find a fix ‚Üí write tests ‚Üí refactor ‚Üí repeat

Here‚Äôs how it works now:

Ask an AI to generate the code ‚Üí review ‚Üí tweak logic in natural language ‚Üí fix minor issues myself, if any ‚Üí ask AI to fix major ones ‚Üí repeat

Do you see the difference?

I no longer write the code from scratch anymore, an AI does it for me!

I‚Äôve measured my productivity and there‚Äôs no question: I get more done with AI. It allows me to scaffold features in minutes, complete with tests and documentation, things that used to take hours before ü§Ø

But here‚Äôs my concern‚Ä¶

What about the new generation of developers?

For them, writing code from scratch will feel as outdated as handwriting for everything today. And just like handwriting, the craftsmanship of coding is doomed to fade (not completely, but significantly).

Think about it. A century ago, handwriting was such a crucial skill, people took pride in their calligraphy. Today, "writing" no longer means putting words with a pen on paper, now it‚Äôs about structuring readable ideas in a digital format.

The same shift is happening in coding. The act of "writing code" will be automated. What will remain is the higher-order skill of thinking systematically in a way that could guide an AI to turn ideas into executable programs that deliver some sort of value.

So, a few questions before ending this rambling: 

Should we still teach coding the hard way (i.e., without AI) like we still teach handwriting in schools? Or will that just feel awkward and outdated? Are we gonna lose the ability to write code from scratch?

I don‚Äôt know. Most of us don‚Äôt hunt or gather for food anymore, but that doesn't make eating any less satisfying.

Isn‚Äôt?

I had a discussion today that revolved around the following idea: "Websites and APIs (as we know it) are about to die."

Why?

Because soon, AI agents will completely replace them in a way we've never experienced before.

Digital branding will change radically.

AI agents won‚Äôt just absorb a company's data, they‚Äôll control every part of its branding and content strategy.

So what does it mean for us as customers?

We‚Äôll never waste time scrolling through irrelevant products or generic content again. Instead, we‚Äôll interact with an intelligent agentic UI that knows everything about a company but only presents what we truly want (or are allowed to see).

Think about it. In real life, we don‚Äôt communicate with everyone the same way. We adapt our message based on whom we‚Äôre speaking to and in which environment we are.

Yet today‚Äôs websites and apps treat (almost) every customer identically. AI agents are about to end this impersonal online interaction by creating hyper-personalized experiences (i.e., far beyond simple ML recommendation systems).

The future looks very much agentic, IMHO.

And the black boxes will become even darker üóÉÔ∏è

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 4 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
I‚Äôm totally convinced that career growth isn‚Äôt about climbing a title ladder.

We tend to position ourselves within specific categories (e.g., developer, senior engineer, staff engineer, director, CEO, you name it), expecting to jump from one to another eventually.

But the real game isn‚Äôt about titles at all, it‚Äôs about conquering complexity.

Why?

Because the amount of value we can create is directly tied to the level of complexity at which we operate.

Here‚Äôs a simple heuristic for assessing where you are in our careers and how to reach the next level:

üîπ First, you‚Äôre told WHAT to do AND HOW to do it (e.g., junior engineer).
üîπ Then, you‚Äôre just told WHAT to do (e.g., senior engineer).
üîπ Next, you‚Äôre ASKED HOW to do it (e.g., staff engineer).
üîπ Eventually, you‚Äôll be ASKED WHAT should be done (e.g., director).
üîπ Finally, no one tells or asks you ANYTHING, you‚Äôll set the goals yourself (e.g., executive level).

Do you see it?

Each step you climb makes you less vulnerable because the amount of value you can deliver increases exponentially. And this happens because your capacity to handle more complexity increases. Low complexity ‚Üí staying at the bottom ‚Üí higher risk of being replaced.

So, our real career growth is actually shaped by the challenges we must conquer to climb the complexity ladder.

For example, here‚Äôs a roadmap for developers:

1Ô∏è‚É£ First, we must master the art of managing complexity in code. We should learn algorithms, exploratory data analysis (EDA), software architecture, and so.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Second, knowing how to code isn‚Äôt enough. We must identify which problems are worth solving. The complexity here lies in navigating uncertainty and delivering real-world value.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Third, we must make sense of chaos. Leaders at the highest levels don‚Äôt just solve problems, they choose which problems matter. They craft narratives, shape strategies, and define purpose.

So, let‚Äôs stop obsessing over titles. Instead, let‚Äôs ask ourselves: "Which layer am I in, and what level of complexity am I ready to conquer next?‚Äù

That‚Äôs how real growth happens ü™ú

P.S. This post was inspired by the following piece https://lnkd.in/dRy6dq9y, all the credit to its author.

posts.text:
I really enjoyed the session today about AI Agents at Google's headquarters in Stockholm, organized by The AI Community of Sweden.

What did I learn?

‚Ü≥ Building and SELLING AI agentic ecosystems is a brand-new BIG business opportunity, and some of the biggest players in the tech industry are ready to jump in.

Big companies like Google can integrate existing apps (Jira, Teams, Gmail, etc.) into their cloud platforms. This creates an environment where tailored AI agents can interact, take action, and deliver value without human intervention.

I believe this technology has the potential to accelerate processes with incredible efficiency.

For example, I just watched a demo of the coming Google Agentspace. The deployment of agents there allowed the creation of a live onboarding guide for new hires... in seconds! The key innovation is that it continuously updates with information that is specific to the given employee role.

Here are some of the most interesting features of agentic ecosystems:

üîπ Task sharing: AI agents can pass tasks to each other to complete more complex activities.

üîπ Guardrails: We can impose restrictions on the agents to regulate their actions (to some extent).

üîπ Action logs: We‚Äôll have detailed logs (a.k.a. traces) showing exactly what AI agents are doing at each step.

Just as cloud services revolutionized IT infrastructure a few years ago, agentic ecosystems scale very well and can be applied to practically any use case involving automation. The competition will be fierce in this space. Ouch. 

In the meantime, I can only hope this will help cut down bureaucracy and paperwork across industries.

We‚Äôll see üçø

P.S. The presenters: Frode Langmoen, Nikola Rubil, and Janner Caner Kilinc.

posted_at.relative: 4 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
I just finished reading a recent paper that explores the potential of applying agentic workflows to financial services.

It‚Äôs very clear (to me) that traditional methods for handling financial assets will fall behind quite soon, given the huge advantages of AI-powered systems.

The current LLMs-based technology allows building specialized agents for almost every financial task. From feature engineering to model evaluation, these systems deliver the precision and resilience that traditional methods simply cannot.

Concretely, the paper focuses on two use cases for agentic AI systems:

1Ô∏è‚É£ FINANCIAL MODELING: The agentic crew consists of a manager and multiple agents who perform specific tasks such as exploratory data analysis, feature engineering, model selection, hyperparameter tuning, model training, model evaluation, and writing documentation.

2Ô∏è‚É£ MODEL RISK MANAGEMENT: The agentic  crew consists of a manager along with specialized agents who perform tasks such as checking compliance of modeling documentation, model replication, conceptual soundness, analysis of outcomes, and writing documentation.

The results show that AI agents can effectively collaborate to perform these complex tasks in real-time.

The agents were able to streamline the modeling workflow, carry out model risk management procedures on a trained model, and effectively manage dependencies as well as collaboration among other agents.

The novelty of these models is that they learn, adapt, and evolve by themselves. For example, they can detect fraud with unprecedented accuracy, approve credit with confidence, and manage portfolio risk with unmatched efficiency.

Eventually, there will be adaptive learning agents that continuously improve their performance through past interactions and the various feedback they receive. Another even more interesting improvement will be agents capable of developing their own agents, tools, and tasks required for specific operations.

Are we about to reach the next frontier in financial modeling?

Or have we already surpassed it?

I got it: AI Engineering ‚â† ML Engineering.

The world has changed, and so has the way we build modern apps.

Why?

1Ô∏è‚É£ Traditional ML requires us to train models from scratch.

AI engineering, however, is about leveraging pre-trained foundation models. Our focus now is on rapid model adaptation through data and prompting.

2Ô∏è‚É£ AI models produce open-ended outputs, which significantly complicates evaluation.

But success has measurable value. If our evaluation methods aren‚Äôt robust, our projects will fail.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Foundation models are massive, resource-intensive, and slow.

This isn‚Äôt just inconvenient, it creates an urgent demand for engineers skilled in GPU management, efficient model training, and optimization. Without these skills, the most ambitious AI projects risk never reaching production.

So, to succeed today as a Data Scientist, mastering the following skills isn‚Äôt optional:

‚Üí Prompt engineering: Powerful, nuanced, and surprisingly impactful.

‚Üí Data engineering for production: Essential for scaling, managing resources effectively, and ensuring our AI solutions are robust and deployable.

‚Üí Fine-tuning smaller models: Complex, requiring more data and expertise, but offering dramatic improvements in performance, latency, and cost.

Last but not least, working with frameworks like Hugging Face and LangChain, and learning Data Engineering skills for production-ready deployment is super relevant.

posts.text:
What's the actual difference between invention and innovation?

Invention ‚Üí It‚Äôs about creating something novel, perhaps ingenious, yet it doesn‚Äôt imply anyone actually needs or wants it.

Innovation ‚Üí It occurs when an invention addresses real-world problems (e.g., when customers find that a product is actually usable).

Customer-centricity, therefore, acts as the catalyst, transforming abstract inventions into impactful innovations.

In the #AI field, I think we often celebrate inventions: new models with groundbreaking performance, papers that set benchmarks, or novel frameworks that speed up prototyping. Yet, true innovation occurs only when these powerful ideas and tools meet genuine user needs (i.e., when AI becomes customer-centric).

For example, the invention of #LLMs was impressive, but it became innovative only when products like ChatGPT made them accessible, intuitive, and impactful for millions of everyday users.

On the other hand, sometimes inventions are ahead of their time precisely because they're too customer-centric. They assume customer needs that don't yet exist or aren't yet understood (e.g., Microsoft‚Äôs Clippy).

Today, I believe many AI startups fail because they're too "ahead of their users," disconnected from real-world needs. They're brilliant, but not relatable.

It‚Äôs the deliberate act of understanding and anticipating customer desires (and frustrations) the thing that transforms impressive AI inventions into powerful innovations.

Corollary ‚Üí Invention alone isn't enough.

It is the act of understanding users that actually turns inventions into impactful innovations. 

So let‚Äôs keep creating new things with curiosity, but innovate with empathy and common sense. 

Wishing you a great weekend!¬†üòâ

posts.text:
Two years ago, I made a huge mistake in a job interview.

I was in the company's lobby, waiting for my turn. But my interviewer wasn‚Äôt waiting for me there. I expected the interview to start at 15:00, and at 15:15, I asked the receptionist if I could somehow contact him.

So she called the interviewer. While waiting, I checked my phone, and my heart sank.

The interview was supposed to start at 14:00. For some reason, I thought it was at 15:00. Bang!

I was 1 hour late.

At that moment, I felt like a complete failure, but I was already there, and running away from trouble is not my thing.

The interviewer arrived at 15:30.

We shook hands, and he led me into a meeting room.

I didn‚Äôt make excuses. I didn‚Äôt try to justify it. I just apologized (a lot).

He simply said once: "Let's leave it behind."

That was it.

For the next 2 hours, I had one of the most engaging technical discussions of my life.

Looking back, I wonder: How often do we hold onto someone else‚Äôs mistake instead of letting it go?

How many times have I let frustration cloud my judgment when someone disappointed me?

That day, I learned something more valuable than any job offer: The ability to forgive and move on is a rare strength.

I didn‚Äôt get the job in the end, but I walked away with a far greater and more valuable experience.

Leave the past behind. Give people grace. You never know what impact it might have.

Cheers! ü•Ç

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 5 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
Why is it impossible to compress all human knowledge into an AI model?

I could hardly imagine a world where every published book, every scientific discovery ever made, and every human thought is compressed into a single AI that knows EVERYTHING.

Nevertheless, it sounds like the ultimate achievement, right? 

But this type of data compression has fundamental limits, dictated by Kolmogorov complexity, Shannon‚Äôs information theory, and the nature of knowledge.

Let's have a deeper look at these three limitations:

1Ô∏è‚É£ The shortest possible description of any dataset is its Kolmogorov complexity. It represents the length of the smallest algorithm that can generate it. It is uncomputable in the general case, meaning no algorithm can determine the absolute shortest representation of arbitrary data.

Furthermore, some sequences have no algorithmically shorter description than themselves, they are incompressible. While much of human knowledge follows structured patterns, large portions contain chaotic unpredictability, making a truly lossless compression of everything fundamentally impossible.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Shannon‚Äôs information theory defines entropy as the minimum number of bits needed to optimally encode a message. High-entropy data has less redundancy and cannot be compressed beyond a fundamental limit.

The problem is that not all human knowledge is low-entropy. While structured facts can be compressed efficiently, much of what we call "knowledge" includes uncertainty, noise, ambiguity, and subjective interpretation. Some knowledge is inherently probabilistic, meaning it lacks a fully deterministic structure that allows for compression.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Even if we could encode all knowledge at one moment, it would immediately become outdated. Knowledge is non-stationary, i.e., it is not a fixed dataset but an evolving process.

New discoveries invalidate old assumptions, cultural contexts shift, and scientific revolutions rewrite fundamental truths. A model that captures "everything" today will still fail to encapsulate what comes next.

So what?

AI models, no matter how advanced, function as approximate compression algorithms: identifying patterns, reducing complexity, and reconstructing knowledge efficiently. 

But as just discussed, compression is never perfect.

Something is always lost. And what‚Äôs lost might be the very essence of intelligence itself: intuition, serendipity, and the unforeseen connections that drive human creativity.

So, would it ever be possible to build a super-intelligent AI that encapsulates everything?

No.

And even though the latest AI models seem to be very competent (think of ChatGPT 4.5 and o1),... folks, let‚Äôs not forget the fundamental limits of what is truly possible üß†

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 5 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
I've always been fascinated by how months of computation and vast amounts of knowledge can be distilled into a single array of bytes that fits in memory.

In ML, a ton of data massaging work, terabytes of information, and countless hours of computation can fit into a single file (a.k.a. the trained model ready for deployment).

As a data scientist, my job often comes down to delivering this model file to be seamlessly integrated into an MLOps pipeline. Once delivered, the file could be loaded to perform inference on real-time and real-world data.

What‚Äôs inside?

That file encodes what the model have  learned. The weights and biases that determine how it makes predictions. Combined with its architecture (in the case of neural networks) or parameters (for statistical models), this forms the brain of an AI system.

But this brain is actually patterns extracted from massive datasets, fine-tuned neural network weights, decision tree splits, and distilled knowledge from everything the model has learned. And yet, all of this is stored in a file formatted as .pth (PyTorch), .ckpt (TensorFlow), .h5 (Keras), or the novel .safetensors (Hugging Face).

Take these examples:

‚Ä¢ An XGBoost model trained on millions of data points, with a limited number of trees and controlled depth, can fit into a few megabytes and make predictions in milliseconds.

‚Ä¢ A computer vision model, trained on millions of images, can be optimized and quantized to run efficiently on a smartphone.

‚Ä¢ A LLM like GPT-4, trained on trillions of words and distilled into a highly optimized terabytes model, can predict the next token with sub-second latency on high-performance hardware.

Every model file represents months of human effort: cleaning data, optimizing pipelines, running experiments, and fine-tuning parameters until it‚Äôs ready for deployment.

Now my question is: 

Is it possible to digitally compress everything, inc. all the human knowledge?

The answer is (fortunately?) negative, and it's due to fundamental limits imposed by information theory, Kolmogorov complexity, and the nature of data entropy.

But that‚Äôs a topic for tomorrow's post üòâ

posts.text:
The openness of LLM training data is already being exploited to inject harmful information into AI systems.

This practice is called ‚Äúmodel poisoning,‚Äù and it‚Äôs a growing threat ‚ö†Ô∏è

Today‚Äôs models could be easily compromised with false or misleading data, forever distorting the outputs they generate.

For example:

What do you think would happens if malicious actors flood popular forums with misleading political statements or fake news during election campaigns? Current LLMs "learn" from these false narratives and, in turn, generate biased or factually incorrect information that is hard to revert, perpetuating a misinformation cycle ‚ôªÔ∏è

Here's how to prevent model poisoning:

‚úì Curate and filter training data meticulously.
‚úì Use anomaly detection to spot strange patterns.
‚úì Apply techniques like differential privacy and adversarial training to strengthen models.
‚úì Regularly audit and monitor models to detect any signs of poisoning.
‚úì Limit data source access, rely on trusted datasets, and consider synthetic data.
‚úì Collaborate with experts, share knowledge, and retrain models periodically to stay ahead.

The above techniques are a good start; however, as AI-generated content floods the internet, future models will inevitably be trained on it. Indeed, research shows that we‚Äôre already running out of public high quality training data ü§Ø 

This could create an endless loop of AI generated data also used for training that‚Äôs harder to control.

Another big problem is data retention. If an already deleted piece of information was part of an LLM's training data, the model might still generate and share it, potentially exposing removed material. Meaning everything you put online will be "remembered" by an AI model, whether you want it or not.

So, the question is:

How do we ensure models are trained from trustful data sources and forget harmful information they‚Äôve learned?

These are an open research questions that I find very interesting, and it‚Äôs not just about preventing ‚Äúmodel poisoning.‚Äù It‚Äôs about preserving the integrity of the entire AI ecosystem.

We need to solve these kind of issues before the whole system completely swallows itself ‚è≥

posts.text:
Want to quickly estimate how long it takes for an investment to double in value?

You don‚Äôt need a calculator. The "Rule of 72" is a quick mental math hack that gives you the answer. This simple formula (derived from the logarithmic formula for compound interest) lets you estimate how long it‚Äôll take for an investment to reach 2x its value, based on a fixed annual return.

Here‚Äôs how it works:

Years to Double = 72 / rate of return (r)

That‚Äôs it. Just one number to keep in mind.

For example, if your investment grows at 8% per year, it will take:

72 / 8 = 9 years to reach 2x its value

Here's why I use the Rule of 72:

‚Üí Quick mental math to estimate returns for interest rates between 6% and 10%.
‚Üí Works for inflation, population growth, and investment returns.
‚Üí Simple but powerful trick for quick financial decisions.

üåü Pro tip: For rates under 6%, use 69 instead of 72 for more accuracy. For rates over 10%, use 75 to get closer to the truth.

posts.text:
How are the hyperparameters of LLMs fine-tuned without blowing up already massive budgets? üí∞

As we know, when training "small" ML models, we can afford to test different hyperparameters repeatedly, tweaking them until we get the best results. But with LLMs? There‚Äôs usually only one shot at training.

So, I just went deep into different hyperparameter tuning techniques for LLMs and discovered the concept of "scaling extrapolation."

In essence, it‚Äôs the process of predicting which hyperparameters will work best on large models based on testing smaller ones. Scaling extrapolation is crucial because training large models is a massive resource drain, and we just can‚Äôt afford to mess around with endless combinations.

Why does it works?

Empirical research has shown that many optimal hyperparameters remain stable when model size changes. For example, a 2022 paper from researchers at Microsoft and OpenAI demonstrated that it is possible to transfer hyperparameters from a 40M model to a 6.7B model: üîó https://lnkd.in/dY3Ef6Vk

Interestingly, scaling extrapolation is still a niche field, tackled by only a few experts.

Why?

Because it‚Äôs incredibly complex. If we have just 10 hyperparameters, we‚Äôre already looking at over 1,000 combinations to test. The complexity explodes as more hyperparameters interact with each other.

I find this challenge fascinating.

For now, it‚Äôs very unlikely that will be working on training large models at this scale. However, what seemed large two years ago is considered small today. Staying ahead means knowing about techniques (like scaling extrapolation) before they become essential. This is how we break through.

Want to dive deeper into scaling extrapolation? Check out this insightful blog post: üîó https://lnkd.in/dhMctqYc by luke metz.

There‚Äôs no doubt: hyperparameter tuning has already reached the next level üöÄ

posts.text:
Can current AI models really make money as a freelance software developer?

Researchers at OpenAI just tackled the million-dollar question, literally üíµ

Their latest research introduces SWE-Lancer, a benchmark built from 1,488 real freelance software engineering tasks on Upwork, collectively worth $1 million in payouts.

Unlike previous benchmarks that rely on unit tests, SWE-Lancer evaluates AI like a real hiring manager would, i.e., by grading tasks with full end-to-end tests, triple-verified by senior engineers.

This is the first benchmark to map AI coding performance to actual $$$ earned. It includes everything from $50 bug fixes to $32,000 full-stack feature builds, covering web, mobile, APIs, and cross-codebase interactions.

The initial benchmark results? 

Well... the paper claims that AI still falls short, but I believe the results are already quite impressive.

The best model, Claude 3.5 Sonnet, managed to earn $208,050 out of a possible $500,800 in the SWE-Lancer Diamond subset. On the full dataset, it scraped together $400,000 out of $1 million. Of course, still not quite there yet to fully replacing human engineers, but already BIG if we consider it‚Äôs just the beginning.

What‚Äôs next?

AI-assisted software development will reshape the job market (without any doubt) especially for freelancers and junior engineers (as stated in the ‚ÄúImpact Statement‚Äù section 7 in the paper). However, we're still far from having fully autonomous AI engineers. More importantly, AI-generated code also comes with serious risks. For example, security vulnerabilities, bad architecture, and potential model autonomy concerns.

Nevertheless, the road to fully autonomous AI-driven software engineering could be shorter than we think! ü§ñ
