posts.text:
This may sound like a truism, but over time, I‚Äôve realized that it‚Äôs 1,000x easier to tell others what needs to be done than to actually do the thing. 

For example, I remember when I was grinding my PhD, it was very easy for my supervisor and colleagues to come up with interesting ideas about my research. They seemed to know better than I what the ‚Äúobvious‚Äù next step was. However, I was the one who had to do the hard work: write the code, run the experiments, write the paper‚Ä¶ (the list goes on).

Throughout our lives, there are always people around us who seem to know what we need to do: first our parents, then friends, colleagues, and managers at work. This doesn‚Äôt necessarily make things easier, even though it may create the illusion that it does.

Because here‚Äôs the thing: today, step-by-step guides exist for almost any ‚Äúhard‚Äù problem. But having a roadmap doesn‚Äôt mean reaching the destination.

Today, with super-powerful AIs in our pockets, we all have access to artificial agents that can quickly list the steps needed to solve difficult problems. Yet, most of us still don‚Äôt succeed at it. Why? I believe it‚Äôs because of time. We need time to prepare, plan, and execute everything!

So, whenever you give advice to somebody else, don‚Äôt just throw out your ideas. Instead, break them down and estimate the time it actually takes to accomplish each step.

We are all free to share ideas, but let‚Äôs not forget that ideas are cheap.

Execution is what truly matters!

posted_at.relative: 5 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
Foundational models have radically changed the way we build and ship AI apps these days.

In traditional ML, we start by gathering DATA, move on to training and evaluating a MODEL, and only then (and depending on the results) is that we focus on enhancing the PRODUCT. This approach has its merits, e.g., we can fine-tune the model to meet our specific needs and ensure that the data is good enough before launching. However, with pre-trained models already available, this process is painfully slow and inefficient. Why? Because we could spend weeks or months gathering the right data and fine-tuning our model(s)... while the product remains in a constant flux.

Thankfully, we don‚Äôt need to follow that path anymore.

When building on top of foundational models, instead of getting stuck in endless data wrangling, we can start by building the product with AI-generated data and see if it works for a pilot number of users. Once we‚Äôve got something promising, we can do real data and model optimizations. 

I find this shift a game-changer!

It isn‚Äôt about creating better user interfaces powered by AI, it‚Äôs about getting the product to market faster. And that means we can start understanding real user needs much earlier, adapt quickly, and iterate faster.

For example, imagine you‚Äôre developing a new app aimed at helping small businesses manage their finances. Before, you would have spent months analyzing customer data, cleaning it, and fine-tuning a model. But then, after a while, you find out the users didn‚Äôt actually want to reduce expenses, what they wanted was to better understand customers to maximize ROI instead. By leading with the product first, we could have launched an early version, gathered ROI feedback, and launched accordingly without waiting for Model v1.0 to be ready.

So, getting to market faster is a huge advantage. The quicker we get the feedback, the quicker we can adjust, and the better we can refine our offering to match what users ACTUALLY want, not just what we think they want üòâ

We don‚Äôt need perfect data, we need quicker insights. We can build, test, and adjust along the way.

Just start building, and let it go üöÄ

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 5 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
Big tech companies are once again pushing employees back to the office with the argument of "increased productivity." 

It‚Äôs a quiet and effective way to cut staff without mass layoffs.

Now, some companies are going further, proposing pay cuts for remote workers. Wait, what? They claim that remote work is a "benefit" and should come at a cost. 

I think this doesn't make any sense:

‚ù∂ Companies save on office space, utilities, and logistics when employees work remotely. In fact, keeping employees on-site is far less cost-efficient.

‚ù∑ If a company bans remote work, probably one of the following is true:

‚Üí It lacks the infrastructure to support it.
‚Üí It doesn't trust its employees.

Neither is a good sign.

‚ù∏ Personally, my best creative moments come when I change my environment. Sitting in the same office all day drains my energy (even more so than working fully remotely). 

The best balance is hybrid: structured for collaboration and flexible enough for deep focus.

To my surprise, some studies suggest that many tech workers would be willing to take a 25% salary cut for the privilege of remote work ü§Ø

The real question isn‚Äôt if tech companies should allow remote work or not; it‚Äôs how it's possible for them (and us) to even consider going back to full-time on-site workstations.

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 5 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
The traditional computer science education system MUST change radically as AI becomes truly ubiquitous.

In the past... do you remember? It was all about having the right knowledge and  "programmer's mindset." We started by learning pseudocode, picking a language, and reading books that began with a bunch of syntax before diving deep into classical algorithms and data structures. Solving problems from scratch has been the pillar of traditional computer science education for a long time!

But today, all of this seems irrelevant to me. Why?

Because nearly every small coding problem I can think of has already been solved, and the unsolved ones are too big for me to solve alone. Furthermore, AI-powered coding assistants can generate high-quality code faster than I ever could. With a simple prompt, they can build entire applications, optimize algorithms, and refactor complex codebases.

So, do we still need to know the nitty-gritty details of syntax and classical algorithms?

Probably not.

‚Üí Manually implementing a sorting algorithm? ‚ùå 

‚Üí Understanding the nuances of pointer arithmetic in C? ‚ùå 

‚Üí Memorizing syntax rules for multiple programming languages? ‚ùå 

So, what do we need instead?

‚Üí The ability to ask the right QUESTIONS and EVALUATE AI-generated responses ‚úÖ

These are the new technical skills that will define the future of learning (in almost every other field, I believe).

Our education system needs to shift accordingly. Instead of emphasizing rote memorization, we must cultivate a mindset of questioning EVERYTHING and rigorously verifying AI-generated answers.

The result of this upcoming educational transformation is uncertain.

But‚Ä¶

I don‚Äôt see any other way forward ü§î

P.S. Disagreement and discussion about this matter are welcome.

posts.text:
Game Development and AI Engineering have so much to learn from each other.

This was my take after attending Alexander Chatzizacharias‚Äô talk at Jfokus this year titled ‚ÄúWhat is Multimodal RAG, and Can You Build a Village with It?‚Äù It was a perfect mix of education and seemingly (absurd?) fun, inspiring anyone to explore the potential of multimodal RAG in the gaming industry.

For those unfamiliar, Multimodal Retrieval-Augmented Generation (MRAG) is the technique of combining your own textual, visual, and audio data to enrich prompts before they‚Äôre processed by GenAI. Imagine a user asks a question, and the system digs into a personalized data pool for context, and then through GenAI it delivers a coherent, relevant response.

We can use multimodal RAG in video games, and I‚Äôm particularly excited about MRAG‚Äôs potential to create games that are both more engaging and intellectually stimulating.

Traditionally, Non-Player Characters (NPCs) rely on static, hardcoded responses. But with MRAG, we can make them dynamic, lifelike, and far more engaging to interact with. For example, we can build NPCs that not only respond intelligently but also interact with each other, pursue goals, and move dynamically within the game world (all powered by complex RAG workflows).

This is exactly what Alexander explored in his session, and it‚Äôs a game-changer. He showed how much more fun it could be for gamers to interact with NPCs that are smart enough to search for and display multimedia assets. 

Two examples: 1Ô∏è‚É£ an NPC finding and playing a metal song that matches the player‚Äôs mood in a specific game scenario, or 2Ô∏è‚É£ interpreting the player‚Äôs own paintings in real-time.

Cool, huh?

posts.text:
My research work has just reached 700 citations on Google Scholar, and I would like to reflect on it.

7x100 might sound like a small number for seasoned researchers, but for me, it‚Äôs a milestone. Why? Because it feels incredible to see that my work has made at least a tiny impact, being referenced by researchers worldwide.

Do citations matter?

Well, yes‚Ä¶ but maybe not in the way you‚Äôd think.

Citations are often seen as a benchmark for research impact, but they don't tell the full story. They reflect how often a research paper is used as a foundation for further studies, but they don‚Äôt necessarily measure the quality or depth of contributions. Some of the papers I‚Äôm most proud of have taken years to gain traction (e.g., my DepClean paper currently ranked 1st in my profile took 3 years to get traction), while other papers have got cited quickly due to trending topics or collaborative networks (e.g., my Data Mining in sports paper, ranked 2nd in my profile took me by surprise).

What have I learned about citations?

‚Üí High-quality work, even if initially overlooked, will eventually get cited. The prestige of the journal or conference definitely plays a role, but solid research speaks for itself over time.

‚Üí Co-authoring with researchers from different institutions or disciplines increases exposure, leading to more citations.

‚Üí Even highly specialized research can gain significant attention if it addresses a critical gap or introduces a novel perspective.

For most researchers, the number of citations per year tends to grow linearly but eventually plateaus. I predict mine might actually decrease this year, as I‚Äôve mostly stepped away from academia üòÅ 

That said, I‚Äôm still open to academic research collaborations!

If you‚Äôre working on something exciting and think we could collaborate, feel free to reach out üôÇ

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 5 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
Documenting source code is a waste of time and space nowadays üóëÔ∏è

I still remember the days when we were arguing about different documentation practices and paradigms. Then, tools like Doxygen, Javadoc, and Sphinx were created to FORCE us (lazy developers) to explain our code in an organized way using "templates." They extracted API signatures, methods, parameters, and more, transforming them into human-readable form, often in HTML or Markdown formats, so that our colleagues and future versions of ourselves could easily understand what the code was supposed to do.

But our battle tested doc tools are not very useful anymore.

Why?

Because current AI can generate good enough documentation automatically for us. For example, GitHub Copilot's chat can answer the ‚Äúwhat it does‚Äù and the ‚Äúhow it does it‚Äù questions for any function (in milliseconds and with very high accuracy) ü§Ø

So, code documentation has fallen into automation, becoming a commodity.

Indeed, I believe that most code documentation today is actually noise.

Think about it. Today, IDEs help us create meaningful variable names easily. They generate all kinds of templates. Typing is not what slows us down anymore: READING IS! The more code we have to read, the longer it takes to understand what needs to be changed in the codebase. So documentation becomes a waste of time in the eyes of efficient developers.

So, should all comments disappear?

The only scenario in which writing a comment makes sense to me is when we use it to add information about the ‚Äúwhy this way.‚Äù For example, adding a comment when checking for the existence of a specific configuration file in a function to ensure that custom settings load correctly for various deployment environments. This kind of info adds more ‚Äúcontext‚Äù about why the code does what a prompted AI said it does (i.e., it reflects the human decision made along the way).

In essence, future documentation requires a narrative. Without it, you just wind up splatting unnecessary words on a codebase, rather than communicating anything useful to the other devs or their AI partners.

And yes, I‚Äôm sorry for the billions of lines of open-source comments and the many human hours invested in them (nothing wrong because they have helped build the AI models after all).

R.I.P. my dear Javadoc ü™¶

posts.text:
I‚Äôm definitely not interested in ANY job that can or could be automated by an AI today.

.

The crazy progress of AI over the past few years means one thing: our work will have to evolve constantly. But that‚Äôs not a bad thing. It means we‚Äôll be FORCED to keep learning, adapting, and growing.

So, the big question is: which jobs will survive the AI wave?

No one knows for sure ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è 

But there are already some existing tech roles that are at high risk of replacement:

‚ùå Rutinary dev tasks ‚Üí AI-powered tools like GitHub Copilot and ChatGPT can now write boilerplate code, reducing the need for entry level devs who traditionally started their careers handling common and often repetitive coding tasks.

‚ùå Low-level data analysis ‚Üí Many BI dashboards and AI assistants can now interpret trends, generate statistical reports, and more. These tools will sooner or later replace some junior data analyst roles.

‚ùå Manual software testing ‚Üí Automated testing frameworks and AI-powered test generation are already replacing traditional QA roles focused on manual testing.

These are just 3 examples. Arguably, ALL coding jobs could be automated to some extent, posing a real risk to disrupt the dev job market.

One thing is certain: CHANGE is the only constant. If we keep doing the same thing for too long without evolving, our skills will eventually become obsolete.

The ONLY option is to move up the value chain, focusing on high-level problem-solving, creativity, and improving our collaboration with AI.

So let‚Äôs keep learning. Keep sharing. Keep changing.

Because standing still will only lead us to fall behind ‚è≥

posted_at.relative: 5 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
Data is the new oil, and it is being sucked up indiscriminately, without any respect for laws or boundaries üõ¢Ô∏è

OpenAI, Claude, Anthropic, and others have scraped my personal website, my code on GitHub, and all the things I've shared online. They have used MY work to train THEIR models. Now, they‚Äôre claiming this as their data and #profiting from it.

For example, below is the response from ChatGPT when asked about "The Last Paper‚Äôs Myth," something I wrote about last year. The answer reflects many of the ideas I shared back then, and I suspect it‚Äôs (partially) the data they used for training. But there is no link to my post anywhere in the response ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Just to be clear, I‚Äôm VERY happy to share everything I know online, but I don‚Äôt like the idea of others making money from it without providing any sort of #attribution.

It‚Äôs bad, and I‚Äôm concerned about a few things that could go wrong if this continues:

‚Ä¢ It could lead to more content being locked behind paywalls, especially scientific literature (leading to more Elseviers, Springers, etc.). We‚Äôre already seeing this trend!

‚Ä¢ Writers might become discouraged from producing long-form content because it‚Äôs not gratifying to spend hours writing just for the sake of feeding an AI that will plagiarize* and sell their ideas (people like writing for other people, not machines).

‚Ä¢ We could fall into a dangerous cycle of (mis)information convergence, where we simply trust whatever an AI "understands" about a topic. This is very risky for ideological freedom and literacy.

Over the years, we‚Äôve built a system where free, open science coexists together with closed journals and patents. It‚Äôs far from perfect, but at least authorship and attribution are #respected.

The current AI race, however, doesn‚Äôt operate like that at all!

So here I am, once again, tying to rise awareness, and hoping to see truly free, open-code, open-data, and open-weights models to be the ones going first at the end of this AI race.

Time will tell‚Ä¶ ‚åõ

*plagiarize ‚Üí :¬†to steal and pass off (the ideas or words of another) as one's own¬†:¬†use (another's production) without crediting the source (The Merriam-Webster Dictionary).

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posted_at.relative: 6 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
*Multitasking* doesn‚Äôt work, we all know that. But really?

We live in a world where juggling many tasks is hard to avoid. We deal with a bombardment of real-time messaging threads, emails popping up, and online meetings, often all at once. What is worst, this kind of #multitasking is sometimes perceived as a sign of efficiency ü§Ø

In this era of perpetual distraction, understanding the limits of our multitasking capabilities is crucial for optimizing work #performance. 

So, I looked into this topic and stumbled upon an interesting paper from 2011 that showed empirical evidence that multitasking can improve productivity, but only up to a certain point: üîóhttps://lnkd.in/gAvHFfXN

The paper‚Äôs findings are pretty clear: medium multitaskers perform reasonably well when it comes to handling many computer-based multitasking tasks, while high multitaskers suffer from it. However, accuracy declines steadily with increased multitasking, no matter how much you juggle! üôÑ

‚Äú‚Ä¶juggling multiple tasks is much more difficult while balancing on a high wire, where performance mishaps can have serious consequences.‚Äù

The results follow a classic inverted-U curve for productivity: multitasking helps until it doesn't. At first, switching between tasks boosts your mental alertness and efficiency. But after a certain point, switching too often leads to mental #overload, making it harder to maintain focus and accuracy on mid complexity tasks.

So, what does this mean for us in 2025? ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Over the last decade, we‚Äôve exponentially increased the number of information channels we juggle at work. It‚Äôs likely that many of us have BECOME high multitaskers in the process, without even noticing it.

To maintain both speed and accuracy, we should focus on fewer tasks at a time (ideally in sequence, without overlap). And if you ever feel overloaded, take a step back, evaluate your multitasking habits, and aim for that sweet spot where productivity is achieved without compromising #quality.

Seriously, too much multitasking can seriously compromise the quality of our work.

It‚Äôs all about balance and awareness üòâ

*A common form of multitasking occurs when a user shifts attention to perform several independent but concurrent computer-based tasks.

posts.text:
It‚Äôs not about the latest models, expensive GPUs, or overpriced consultants. I think DATA is the only thing that truly matters!!!

I still remember the times when we had multiple Machine Learning algorithms that operated under distinct paradigms (e.g., KNN ‚Üí lazy learning, Bayesian ‚Üí statistical, Random Forest ‚Üí decision trees). Then, everything shifted toward Deep Learning thanks to the availability of powerful hardware. More recently, it all seems to be about leveraging the greatest minds with the best ideas to put them all #together.

But I argue that one thing has remained unchanged: the need to process massive amounts of messy #data, and that this is the everlasting skill ü™Ñ

Just as an example, the creators of DeepSeek shared their model architecture and its trained weights with the world as open-source. But what‚Äôs the one thing they kept completely secret? Their training data ü§î

So, if I could only master ONE skill, it wouldn‚Äôt be tweaking models or fine-tuning hyperparameters. It would be handling data at #scale, i.e., building efficient pipelines, automating workflows, and ensuring data quality. This is a top 1% skill that will remain valuable for decades.

At a high level, there are three fundamental steps:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Extracting data from its source
2Ô∏è‚É£ Transforming and cleaning that data
3Ô∏è‚É£ Delivering the cleaned data optimally to the right destination 

* This process is commonly known as ETL (Extract, Transform, Load).

And sure, building a simple ETL pipeline for an AI system isn‚Äôt hard (most developers can build chatbots easily these days). But the real challenge lies in designing resilient, scalable, and fault-tolerant data systems that can handle ever-growing #complexity.

And that‚Äôs why our dear data engineers aren‚Äôt going anywhere in the years to come üòâ

author.headline: Data Scientist @ SEB ¬∑ PhD in CS ¬∑ Living a dream üá∏üá™

posts.text:
Have you actually noticed the significant improvements in AI recently? üìà

I have, but not that much (as a single user).

Quick recap: last month, OpenAI‚Äôs o3 model surpassed human domain experts by a wide margin on many high-level #benchmarks, the same for the Chinese DeepSeek this month. However, I haven‚Äôt felt the impact personally. Why? Because these advancements now focus on narrowing AI‚Äôs expertise into specific knowledge areas.

Indeed, researchers are now working to automate AI research itself, which could theoretically trigger a rapid increase of scientific #discoveries across specific domains (inc. foundational science).

Let‚Äôs take #software development as an example. To better evaluate AI‚Äôs coding abilities, researchers developed SWE-Bench (a benchmark that tests how well AI can solve actual open issues in popular OSS). Just one year ago, the top verified score was 4.4%, but today, OpenAI‚Äôs o3 model achieves an astonishing 72%. This leap is a milestone toward automating the software craft.

But at the same time, the gap between AI‚Äôs public face and its true capabilities is widening. 

Progress is now measured at the level of AI models with PhD-level expertise in niche areas of knowledge.

This makes it harder for the public and policymakers to grasp AI‚Äôs real progress, much less regulate it effectively.

The risk isn‚Äôt that AI development has stalled. The real danger is that we‚Äôre losing our ability to track where it‚Äôs headed.

Don‚Äôt you think? ü§î

posts.text:
Yesterday, at a workshop, a recently graduated student asked me how he could cold-email managers and talent acquisition partners for job opportunities in a way that would make them take him seriously.

I immediately noticed his frustration for not having prior #experience. He mentioned how this automatically puts him at a disadvantage.

I asked him about his current #approach, and his response went something like this (summarized):

‚ÄúDear M, my name is X, and I have skills in Y and Z, as demonstrated by the successful projects A and B that I‚Äôve completed. I‚Äôm interested in working with you on P, where I can leverage A and B to achieve D. I‚Äôve already applied to the open position you have for P. Regards, X.‚Äù

I suggested he try changing his approach to something like this (summarized):

‚ÄúHi M, I recently came across the article A written by C (the CEO of your company), and her vision V deeply resonates with me because of A and B. I also noticed your LinkedIn post L, and it‚Äôs inspiring to me how you‚Äôre driving progress toward that vision. By the way, my name is X, and I believe we share some common synergies that could lead to meaningful collaboration. I‚Äôd love to learn more about your business and share my ideas regarding P. Cheers, X.‚Äù

Do you see the difference?

The second version demonstrates genuine interest and enthusiasm for the company‚Äôs #goals. It shows that you #understand those goals, provide relevant context, and create a sense of synergy. Finally, it proposes sharing new ideas for free, sparking #curiosity.

I believe that smart people are always on the lookout for other smart people who align with their goals and can identify new OPPORTUNITIES.

Do you agree? üòÉ

posts.text:
The modern equivalent of the aerospace race is now fueled with silicon and driven by AI.

I still remember the stories my parents told me 30 years ago about a bipolar world where the US and USSR were constantly rivaling while the rest of the world watched carefully. The Space Race was a big show of technological #progress in the 1960s.

Today, sometimes I feel like I‚Äôm living in a similar world when reading AI‚Äôs latest news. China and the US are both heavily involved in #creating the most powerful AI system. AGI is no joke ü§ñ

So, I wonder how future generations will remember these times of exponential technological #advancements. And I hope there will NOT be such a thing as AI-driven geopolitical divisions, because we‚Äôve learned our lesson. Have we?

Anyway, as engineers, this opens up a wide range of opportunities to build innovative applications. Whether it‚Äôs OpenAI or DeepSeek, the rapid progress and tech opportunities are #exciting.

We‚Äôll probably remember this period as just another inflection point in human history. And I‚Äôm so glad to be in tech, reading papers, and trying things out-of-the-box as they show up!

Interesting times to live in üòÉ

posts.text:
I wonder what the job market will look like for our children as AI becomes ubiquitous in the next few years ü§î

History gives us some clues. In factories, there were production lines, and manual workers were hands-on, performing repetitive tasks (does that ring a bell, developers?). Later, thanks to automation and digitalization, people had to increase their knowledge of the systems and manage them as engineers.

In a few years, AI agents will take over most engineering jobs. Nevertheless, we will still need to stay close to the #business to #understand it and provide proper instructions to the robots (unless they find a way to make money on their own, which I believe is very unlikely).

This disruption will extend not only to #engineers but also to #managers and all kinds of administrative human employees.

As a countermeasure, many new #regulations will likely emerge, creating jobs focused on managing these AI systems more securely.

After all, we invented Agile, Jira, and other tools that created new roles focused on managing developers. We couldn‚Äôt fully understand how software development worked or how to make software #products. If history repeats itself, the same will happen with AI.

This makes me think:

Does our inability to fully understand AI‚Äôs capabilities will save our jobs in the future? (or maybe I‚Äôm just being overly optimistic).

Anyway, our children will figure it out.

And we‚Äôll all watch as a new world unfolds üçø

posts.text:
I still remember the early days when I had nice train/test sets for evaluating my ML projects üìä

Those days are gone.

When it comes to building modern AI applications, #evaluation has become the pain point.

How do we define ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù for models generating creative, nuanced, or subjective outputs?

It‚Äôs no longer just about technical accuracy, but about #usability and #trustworthiness.

Chip Huyen, author of the book "AI Engineering," shared her perspective on this topic recently:

"As AI systems grow more intelligent, evaluating them becomes exponentially harder. Unlike traditional ML, where you might verify whether an email is spam or not, today‚Äôs AI might summarize a book or write a poem. The result looks coherent, but is it accurate? Often, you need to dive deep to assess quality, making evaluation a silent yet formidable bottleneck."

As engineers, I think we‚Äôll spend much more time creating evaluation metrics that align technical performance with business impact, rather than fine-tuning parameters for our AI models.

AI testers will be in great demand in the near future.

After all, if we can‚Äôt measure success, how can we deliver it?

Link to the podcast interview with Chip Huyen ‚Üí https://lnkd.in/drmA3Mgu

article.subtitle: youtube.com

posted_at.relative: 6 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
Will we ever run out of data to train AI models? ü§ñ

I don‚Äôt think so.

What we called "big data" 10 years ago now feels tiny in the context of AI. 

(If you ask me, the "L" in LLMs feels more like a marketing gimmick than anything else.)

While the era of easy, cheap (free?) text data may be nearing its end, I'm sure that AI engineers will figure it out more #creative and #dynamic ways to get training data.

Here are just two possibilities that come to mind:

1Ô∏è‚É£ AI learning directly through human interaction

Example ‚Üì
Human: Oh, this new toilet paper doesn't do a good job.
AI: Would you like me to help you find one you prefer?
Human: Yes, thanks. I like the soft one from (brand) with the stamped roses.
AI: Would you like to add it to your shopping list?
(Meanwhile, some sensitive training data is subtly sent to the cloud‚Ä¶)

2Ô∏è‚É£ AI learning through interaction with the environment

Example ‚Üì
AI Robot: My entropy parameters suggest I should try something new. What happens if I drop this glass?
Human: Hey! Why did you do that? $%&*$%!
AI (thinking): Dropping a glass from a table elicits strong emotional reactions from humans‚Ä¶ (Some more training data finds its way to the cloud server).

Through conversational AI and real-time feedback, models can evolve dynamically. Learning also extends to simulations, sensors, and real-world interactions üí™

‚ÄúThe beauty of innovation is that we always find a way forward.‚Äù

posts.text:
I‚Äôve realized an interesting measure of personal growth: the ability to perceive more OPPORTUNITIES üëÄ

In short, the more opportunities you see, the more likely you are to be in the right place at the right time.

It's not always easy. For example, when I was a teenager, I didn‚Äôt fully grasp the true importance of active learning and honestly didn‚Äôt know what I wanted to do (I bet many of you felt the same). I studied anyway, maybe because I had plenty of free time, but I wasn‚Äôt entirely convinced it would lead ANYWHERE.

Later, I started following my path, but I was WAITING for opportunities to show up. I had a plan and was working toward it, but deep down, I was more reliant on hope than action.

Today, I see opportunities EVERYWHERE. In fact, there are far too many of them in this digital world. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm baffled when I hear people my age complain about a lack of opportunities.

For me, the real challenge isn‚Äôt finding opportunities, it‚Äôs managing the paradox of choice: How do I #invest my limited #time in the most rewarding one? Because everything has an opportunity cost.

Have you ever thought about this?

PS: This paradox of choice is a concept popularized by psychologist Barry Schwartz in his book ‚ÄúThe Paradox of Choice: Why More Is Less.‚Äù The core idea is that while having some choice is essential for autonomy and well-being, too much choice can lead to decreased happiness and increased regret.

posts.text:
Have you ever had the feeling that something you believe should have already been researched and proven true? ü§î

This happens to me quite often.

And it‚Äôs always #exciting to discover that some of our #intuitions have already been studied, named, and supported by scientific research. 

For example, today I discovered the concept of "prospective hindsight." The idea is that just by imagining that a project has already been completed (whether successfully or not) can enhance our ability to identify reasons for future outcomes.

This insight comes from an influential study by Deborah Mitchell, who explored this concept in her 1989 #paper titled "Back to the Future: Temporal Perspective in the Explanation of Events." The research found that using prospective hindsight can improve decision-making by up to 30%.

This is how it works: envision that the event you‚Äôre planning has already taken place. Then ask yourself:

‚Üí What made it succeed?
‚Üí What caused it to fail?

I apply this technique when writing, as it allows me to uncover blind spots I didn‚Äôt even realize existed. Not only does it force me to #confront hidden #assumptions and #anticipate potential #roadblocks, but it also clarifies the key factors that could propel the task forward. It saves time and resources while instilling clarity and confidence.

You can try it yourself right now. Ready? Here‚Äôs an experiment for you:

Imagine yourself celebrating your biggest success of 2025. Now ask yourself: What decisions, habits, or risks did you take to get there?

Done? Now take ACTION.

‚ÄúThe future isn‚Äôt something we passively stumble into. It‚Äôs built by the questions we dare to ask ourselves today.‚Äù

posts.text:
What is DORA and why should we care about it?

The Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) is a game-changer for the financial industry in the EU. It came into effect last Friday, January 17th, 2025 (yes, politicians deploy on Fridays ü§Ø). DORA pushes financial entities across the EU to meet stricter #standards to stay #resilient against #cyberattacks and ICT #disruptions. üíª‚ö°

If you work in the FinTech sector, DORA is a big deal because:

üîí It enforces robust risk management frameworks to protect systems from breaches and outages.
üì¢ It mandates that firms must report major ICT incidents quickly to tackle threats head-on.
üéØ Expect rigorous operational stress tests, including threat-led penetration testing.
ü§ù It‚Äôs not just banks and financial firms; cloud providers and other ICT vendors must meet compliance too.

For financial institutions üè¶, adapting to DORA is a massive #commitment, perhaps comparable in scale to MiFID and GDPR. A crucial part of this is identifying critical software functions and their dependencies on third-party vendors(ranging from tech giants to smaller SaaS providers). Aligning all these parties with DORA is challenging but necessary to ensure the availability of critical services, even in the face of large-scale cyberattacks.

For developers üßë‚Äçüíª, this means more job #opportunities in the financial industry and a growing demand for enhanced resilience into every software solution we build (i.e., setting stronger security protocols, seamless collaboration with risk teams, and designing systems that can handle critical disruptions in real time).

DORA is not just about compliance, it's a commitment, and a call to action to create a more secure financial ecosystem with operational resilience! üöÄ

How can you become economically successful as a female magician?

This was the question that caught my attention today while attending the event titled ‚ÄúMeeting the A-Players: The Art of Pivoting Your Industry.‚Äù The question was directed to Caroline Ravn, one of the most #successful professional female magicians in the world ü™Ñ

Her response was both #powerful and #inspiring. She emphasized the importance of fully believing in who you want to become and wholeheartedly embracing that identity. She said (to herself) at some point in her career: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to be THE magician girl in a suit and heels, and I‚Äôm also going to educate others on how to win the business game as an entertainer.‚Äù

She also highlighted the value of personal branding in the business world, explaining that ‚Äúpeople start to associate you with positive vibes.‚Äù One practical tip she shared was to practice power posing for at least two minutes daily (a small habit with a big psychological #impact).

I had an amazing time today with such a wonderful crowd of Swedish entrepreneurs. I learned so much from people who are pushing the boundaries of #creativity and #innovation. As someone put it: ‚ÄúEntrepreneurship is sometimes like building a plane while flying it.‚Äù Challenging? Absolutely. But extremely rewarding as well ü¶Ñ

P.S. Caroline wrote a book titled "The Business Side Of Show Business: How To Make A Living Doing Magic" (you can check out the link in the last picture below, it's good stuff üòâ).

posts.text:
What was the biggest challenge you faced during your PhD? What would you have done differently?

These were two questions I received from first-year #WASP PhD students yesterday at the WASP Winter Conference in Norrk√∂ping. I feel incredibly fortunate for the opportunity to be on stage sharing my #experiences and #insights with such talented students!

These were my answers: 

1Ô∏è‚É£ My biggest challenge:
‚ÄúThe hardest part was finding the right balance between working really hard on my PhD (doing a PhD is inherently tough) without compromising my health and avoiding burnout. For me, the real challenge wasn‚Äôt working hard, it was actually knowing when was the right time to stop working and take a pause.‚Äù

2Ô∏è‚É£ What I‚Äôd do differently: 
‚ÄúI regret not planning earlier (at least a year in advance) for what comes after completing the PhD. It‚Äôs common among PhD students to get so deeply immersed in the thing that they forget about everything else, because the PhD becomes part of their identity. But graduating isn‚Äôt the end of the journey, it‚Äôs just the beginning. I recommend start preparing for the next phase before the whirlwind of thesis writing, and the chaos of those final months hits!‚Äù

These are just my personal insights, and every PhD journey is unique‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs what makes it such a special experience!

I‚Äôm grateful for the opportunity to share my stories and engage with #excellent students who will surely become successful researchers and innovators. Many thanks to the WASP ‚Äì Wallenberg AI, Autonomous Systems and Software Program for making this opportunity possible and the dream a reality for so many, and thanks to #Sweden for making research a strategic priority for the benefit of the whole society üòä

I believe most of the current #management #skills will become obsolete in the coming years.

The next wave of management books will likely focus on dealing with #AI #agents instead of humans (i.e., directing AI toward achieving desired outcomes with precision).

In fact, learning how to guide AI-powered systems is as important today as learning how to properly "Google search" was in the 2000s.

If I were a technical manager, here‚Äôs what I would start doing RIGHT NOW to prepare:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Learn Prompt Engineering: Mastering the techniques to ask the right questions and designing inputs to maximize output value of AI tools (e.g., refining context, clarifying intent, and fostering creativity).

2Ô∏è‚É£ Optimize Workflows: Experimenting with integrating AI tools into everyday processes. Identify where they can reduce workload or augment team's outputs (e.g., automating mundane tasks, enhancing decision-making, or streamlining communication workflows).

3Ô∏è‚É£ Develop AI Literacy: Ensuring everyone in the team understands the fundamentals of how AI works and its current limitations.

We are standing at the edge of a radical shift in how cognitive work is managed. Those who adapt early will not just stay relevant, they‚Äôll define the future of enterprise #leadership!

Don‚Äôt you think?

posts.text:
I still hear some developers referring to #AI as a #threat.

While undeniably useful, current AI models have notable limitations in the context of software development.

Here are my 3 favorites:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Lack of Contextual Understanding:¬†AI lacks the domain expertise and intuition required to assess edge cases or fully grasp the implications of design decisions.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Limited Creativity:¬†While AI can recombine existing elements in unexpected ways, its ‚Äúcreativity‚Äù stems from probabilistic reasoning, not from subjective experience, intentionality, or insight.

3Ô∏è‚É£ No Accountability:¬†Software projects don‚Äôt live in isolation, they exist to solve real-world problems. An engineer must account for business needs, user behavior, and technical feasibility, which requires human judgment and responsibility.

So, will AI replace software developers?

I don't think so (at least not anytime soon). But it is fundamentally changing the development landscape, making human creativity and problem-solving capabilities more essential than ever.

Adaptability is one of the most valuable human skills. As long as the world keeps changing, there will always be a need for people who can pivot quickly and come up with creative solutions to the most challenging problems.

It‚Äôs winter now ‚ùÑÔ∏è. I wrote a blog post on this topic during the summer last year üåû (link down below), and my thoughts remain unchanged.

Am I wrong?

posts.text:
Just before starting every new year, I do two exercises that help me  focus on what‚Äôs important and to achieve my personal goals:

1Ô∏è‚É£ ‚ÄúWheel of Life‚Äù

I draw 3 lines intersecting at the center of an imaginary circle to divide it into 8 sections. Each line represents one of the following areas of life: money, family and friends, fun, career, personal growth, health, love, and giving.

I rate my satisfaction in each area on a visual scale by marking dots along the radius of each section. Then, I connect the dots to form a shape within the circle.

The resulting shape gives a visual representation of how "balanced" I feel in life. The parts of the shape that are uneven highlight areas where I should focus more attention to improve in the coming year.

I compare the current shape with the previous year‚Äôs shape and reflect on what has improved and what has declined during that time.

2Ô∏è‚É£ ‚ÄúNew Year Goals‚Äù

I start by revisiting the past year‚Äôs goals and thinking about new goals to improve the current status of my ‚ÄúWheel of Life‚Äù (from exercise 1).

I divide a piece of paper into four quadrants, each representing a quarter of the coming year.

Then, I write no more than 4 goals in each quadrant, following the SMART framework (i.e., Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound).

For example, instead of writing ‚ÄúGetting X certification from Google,‚Äù I write ‚ÄúStudying 4 hours every week to get X certification from Google.‚Äù

I have found that setting smaller goals that are achievable every 3 months works better for me than having bigger yearly goals. The reason is that one year is too much time, and I tend to forget the goals. I also need that dopamine hit that comes just after achieving each goal.

üÜï¬†in 2025, I want to try out the following 3 new productivity hacks:

- Daily focus log (i.e., write down the amount of time I actually focused during the day).

- Weekly review (i.e., spend 15 minutes every Sunday afternoon to look at the status of my quarter and review how it is going).

- Slowing down (i.e., relax more and lower down my expectations of what I can actually achieve during a short period of time). 

Footnote: Numerous studies have shown that writing these things on a piece of paper significantly increases the chances of achieving them.

PS: I you have kids, then you know what the drawings on the back are üòÑ

posted_at.relative: 8 months ago ‚Ä¢ Edited ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
Yesterday, I attended an insightful PyData Meetup in Stockholm, hosted by Solita. Very good discussions there, with highly skilled Data Scientists and hands-on community members.

Below my thoughts on the 2 talks of the day:

1Ô∏è‚É£ "How LLMs work?" by Jonas Thunberg

‚Üí Understanding embeddings is essential: LLMs use multi-head self-attention to determine which vector embedding aligns best in the vector space. This involves leveraging previous words' semantic (more embeddings!) to develop an abstract understanding of the text‚Äôs meaning.

‚Üí Matrices are everywhere: The fundamental math behind all this stuff is basic operations over matrices and in particular matrix multiplication (that's why GPUs are so expensive nowadays).

ü§î I have a question for companies:

‚Üí Do you seek for experts who truly understand the intricate math behind these technologies, or do you prefer speed and practical skills for rapid deployment instead?

2Ô∏è‚É£"Building RAG for Financial Data" by Dmitrii Shiriaev

‚Üí RAG is probably the most applicable AI approach for companies at the moment. It requires "knowing" and applying many tricks to accurately extract insights from data to enhance search capabilities (e.g., parsing double-column PDFs, or decoding figures to answer specific business questions). So, it looks to me that "Data Scientist" are now turned into "Search Scientists".

‚Üí The RAG community lacks open resources to learn the best tricks out there. We still have Kaggle for traditional ML knowledge sharing (e.g., for fine tuning models), but current RAG knowledge is mostly empirical, driven by hands-on experimentation with messy corporate internal data.

ü§î One thought on this:

‚Üí Many companies are cautious about deploying RAG solutions directly to customers due to potential risks of losing credibility and prestige if some responses are wrong. Building trust in these technologies is still WIP. But we'll get there soon.

Have a great weekend folks!

PS: Many thanks to Sebastian Wallk√∂tter, Ph.D. for arranging and coordinating the event.

Six years ago, the WASP ‚Äì Wallenberg AI, Autonomous Systems and Software Program changed my career & life, opening the door to perform first-class academic research in Sweden.

WASP is an initiative from the ‚ÄúKnut and Alice Wallenberg Foundation‚Äù, one of Europe's largest private funders of scientific research. It has graduated over 100 PhD students, and there are 460 on their way. Every week, a new WASP PhD student receives a diploma. Isn't that AMAZING? 

But for any WASP alumni (like me) completing a PhD is just the beginning of another exciting journey.

At this year's "WASP Academia and Industry Days," the conversation centered on maximizing the unique human resources and opportunities WASP has cultivated in the field of #AI.

The Big Question: How can Sweden best leverage this exceptional pool of talent?

One (of the) Answer/s: WASP believes it is possible to drive more innovation and progress in #Sweden by lowering the barriers of collaboration between academia and industry.

Now @ SEB, I can continue contributing to WASP's vision.

So glad to be part of this!

Feeling amazing speaking @ SEB Tech Day, what a magnificent event BTW!

My talk this year was about the AI buzz, the misconceptions around it, its true capabilities, and why (I believe) Machine Learning is still the most impactful AI related tech for businesses - until proven otherwise ü´§

From AI's theoretical beginnings in 1943 to its practical applications in the financial sector, the goal of my 15 mins talk was to offer a fresh perspective on GenAI‚Äôs real value today and its (promising) future.

My 3 Key Takeaways:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Predictive AI (a.k.a. Machine Learning) has already proven its worth in production: it's fast, accurate, and reliable.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Generative AI (a.k.a. "Intelligent Systems", sort to speak) has incredible potential but still faces limitations.

3Ô∏è‚É£ The synergy between GenAI and ML unlocks exciting new possibilities, driving better customer services and allowing smarter business decisions.

PS: Many thanks to SEB for always supporting developers and giving me the opportunity to share my perspective about tech, science, and beyond üòä

posted_at.relative: 11 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
Everywhere, I see computer scientists that look like they are working on the right thing ü§î

They spent a long time discussing the thing, writing code to run it (in the best cases), and collecting results.

Then, they publish the thing üéâ

However, many times "the thing" is either worthless or just doesn't work as claimed.

This isn't a new issue. In 1974, the American physicist Richard Feynman coined the term "cargo cult science" to describe the exact same phenomenon.

I wrote a blog post reflecting on his ideas through the lens of someone who has experienced the pressures of producing science "the modern way."

My core takeaway? Despite systemic pressures, I think it‚Äôs still possible to do "the right thing" and land the plane without falling into the trap of cargo cult science üõ¨ 

#CargoCultScience #ComputerScience #ScientificIntegrity

posted_at.relative: 11 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn

posts.text:
I attended a great BFSI after-work event this week at Amazon Web Services (AWS), hosted by Couchbase and Playground Data. There were top-notch presentations, demos, and a well-moderated Q&A session at the end (not to mention the fantastic boat trip across Stockholm's archipelago).

Here are 3 nuggets from the meta-discussion that I still remember:

1. Q: Is choosing a dedicated database always the best option?¬†A: It's important to select a database that best fits the requirements of each specific use case. However, there‚Äôs always a trade-off regarding how much versatility is sacrificed in exchange for performance and vice versa.

2. Q: To what extent does it make sense for an organization to pursue a multi-cloud strategy? A: It enhances resilience, avoids vendor lock-in, and optimizes costs across various services. However, spreading resources across multiple clouds also increases complexity, requiring additional expertise and human talent to manage it effectively.

3. Q: What are proven ways to leverage AI as a key driver for tech transformation in the financial sector?¬†A: AI has shown to be a workhorse in the sector, inc. predictive analytics, automating routine processes, and enhancing customer experiences through personalized services. However, it‚Äôs not a silver bullet, particularly when it comes to building trust and ensuring the reliability of customer-facing services.

Many thanks to Joakim Karlsson for the invitation üôÇ

posts.text:
Would you trust a cracked version of an app downloaded from a random website‚ùì
No, (I hope) you don't‚ùó

Would you trust that your latest purchase will be processed correctly by your bank's mobile app‚ùì
Sure, you (probably) do‚ùóÔ∏è

We all agree that payment systems are more secure than cracked apps. This is because our sense of "trust" in software varies significantly depending on its origins and the reputation of its distributors.

But...

Forty years ago, in a memorable Turing Award talk titled ‚ÄúReflections on Trusting Trust‚Äù, Ken Thompson brilliantly demonstrated that ‚ÄúYou cannot trust code that you did not totally create yourself‚Äù, and that it doesn‚Äôt matter whether it's a pirated app or a bank app. 

I find his method for proving this claim absolutely fascinating. ü§Ø

Indeed, this could be one of the boldest and most thought-provoking ideas in the history of cybersecurity. ‚ú®

I wrote a blog post to revisit Thompson's famous proof of software distrust. ‚úçÔ∏è

Check it out! üëá

#Cybersecurity #History #Compilers

Three years ago, I was struggling (a lot) with writer's block while working on my research papers. üò£

After discussing it with a few colleagues, I realized I was not the only one having a hard time with academic writing. ü§î

So I decided to put all my energy into finding solutions to overcome this issue and improve my writing (crucial for researchers). üîé

To help others in the same situation, I wrote a blog post about my techniques to deal with it (link in the comments üëá).

A few weeks ago, I got interviewed by a journalist from Springer Nature Group who was researching for an article about writer's block and found my blog post. üôÇ

She ended up writing a great article about this topic, which I certainly recommend to all writers facing writer's block. üöÄ

---

Thanks to Emily Sohn for the great conversation. I now have a deeper appreciation of the value of true professional journalists. 

I'm honored that you chose my words as the first quote of your article: üôè 

"Some people choose to do science because they want to do experiments, because they want to write code, because they want to try new things. Then, after they realize that the research is mostly about writing research papers, they struggle a lot because they find out that writing a research paper is very hard."

#Science #Writing #Productivity

üåê The web is (arguably) the only tech platform that has been continuously transformed and evolved at a global scale over the last 30 years. How was this possible? What can we learn from the past technical mistakes and successes? 

My latest blog post addresses these questions, with a focus on the engineering paradigms that marked inflection points in web history. 

Here is a summary of my observations:

üìÑ Simplicity and Efficiency Holds: Foundational web technologies like static HTML and server-side rendering remain useful for delivering content that rarely changes or doesn't require dynamic processing. These technologies were great in the 90s and continue to be effective and cost-efficient solutions even in 2024 for many use cases.

üé® User Experience Matters: From the introduction of CSS for enhanced web aesthetics to the development of SPAs for dynamic user interactions, the focus on improving user experience has led to the creation of more dynamic technologies for real-time DOM manipulation and improved data fetching, leading to better user experience.

‚ö° Interactivity and Real-Time Communication Are Essential: Technologies such as client-side rendering, AJAX, and WebSockets have redefined user engagement, providing experiences as smooth and responsive as those of desktop applications.

üõ°Ô∏è Security and Performance Are Continuous Priorities: Technologies like WebAssembly offer robust security models and enhanced performance, enabling developers to create high-performant applications with improved security features.

üöÄ Innovation and Adaptability is Not Optional: Developers need to remain flexible and embrace new technologies like WebAssembly and dApps to create cutting-edge web applications that meet the expectations of modern users.

"Those who don't know tech history are doomed to repeat past engineering mistakes."

Read more down below üëá

#WorldWideWeb #WebHistory #WebTechnologies

Now is a good time to reflect upon my professional achievements in 2023.

Here are some of my highlights from the year gone by:

* Completed my PhD. I successfully delivered and defended my PhD thesis at KTH Royal Institute of Technology. This is a significant milestone for me after 5 years of dedicated research efforts.

* Landed a great job at SEB. After about 30 job applications, 10 interviews, and a few attractive offers, I happily joined SEB. Now I‚Äôm convinced that I made the right choice. 

* Got a paper accepted at IEEE TSE. I submitted a research paper that got accepted in the journal  Transactions on Software Engineering. This achievement marked a peak in my research career.

* Engaged with the tech community. I attended over 10 technical meetups in Stockholm. This allowed me to connect with the tech community while visiting companies such as Google, Amazon Web Services (AWS), Spotify, Cloudera, Goldman Sachs,  Combient, and more. I also contributed as a volunteer at Jfokus. 

* Expanded my online presence. I wrote 10 blog posts on my website, spoke at 4 events, and was featured in a podcast episode for the first time.

* Kept learning. I improved my Swedish significantly, completed 3 specializations on Coursera, read around 10 technical books, and listened to all episodes of the "Lex Friedman Podcast" and "Software Engineering Radio."

* Committed to fitness. I maintained a steady gym routine, hitting the gym at least 5 times a week, and ran the Blodomloppet Sverige (10km Stockholm‚Äôs half marathon). There is no professional growth without good health, which for me means going to the gym regularly üòÄ

For the next year, my professional focus is to create more technical content (inc. source code) and consume less content in general. 

Wishing everyone a Happy New Year! Let's make 2024 a year of growth and achievement.

Welcome C√©sar Soto Valero to speak at #Jfokus 2024 with a talk about #SBOM: Dancing on Thin Ice - Leveraging Software Bill of Materials
#supplychain #security

The Talk: Dancing on Thin Ice - Leveraging Software Bill of Materials

Are you sure that you know which software you're actually running and delivering to your clients? If your answer is "yes", think twice because most people don't.

To answer this question, the idea of building Software Bill of Materials (SBOMs) has recently emerged as a key concept to enable principled engineering of software supply chains. It extends the well-established concept of a "bill of materials", used in manufacturing physical goods, to the realm of software development. The purpose of SBOMs is to capture relevant information about the internals of a software artifact. This includes a complete inventory of all the third-party dependencies of the artifact and its build environment. Thus, answering the question regarding third-party code provenance.

Whether you‚Äôre a Java security expert or just starting your journey to deploy robust software solutions, this session is for you. We'll delve into checksums, hierarchy, reproducibility, and production steps for SBOM producers. Let's unleash the benefits of using SBOMs to harden the software supply chain of real-world #Java projects! 

More info and registration: buff.ly/3Sd3GjR

Four years ago, we submitted a research paper to the journal IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering (TSE). The paper was REJECTED, but fortunately it was published in another good journal [1]. Two years later, we tried again and submitted another paper to TSE. And again, our paper was REJECTED and later accepted in another good journal [2]. Despite these rejections, we decided to submit the last contribution of my PhD to TSE [3].

Today, after nearly five years of continuous effort, I'm glad to share that the last paper of my PhD journey (and third attempt at TSE) has been ACCEPTED for publication in this reputable journal.

I'd like to extend my heartfelt gratitude to its coauthors Deepika Tiwari, Tim Toady, and Benoit Baudry.

Never underestimate the power of persistence.
Aim high and don't give up! üí™

Almost 5 years ago, I was lucky enough to become a Ph.D. student at KTH Royal Institute of Technology. Today, I‚Äôm proud to say that I successfully defended my thesis  üéØüòÄ üéâ. This is a significant milestone in my life. This is also a new starting point for me to explore software technology and research beyond academia.

Big thanks to my supervisors Benoit Baudry and Martin Monperrus for their unwavering support and insightful guidance throughout this journey. A large part of this success is thanks to you both. Your valuable guidance was key to improving my research work and making solid contributions to the field. Your relentless pursuit of excellence has been a constant inspiration!

Thank you David Broman for chairing the public defense. Thank you Diomidis Spinellis for being the opponent and bringing so many relevant discussions during the defense. Also, big thanks to Valentina Lenarduzzi, Antonino Sabetta, and Philipp Leitner for joining the grading committee and providing great feedback.

Thanks to every member of the ASSERT (Awesome Software Engineering Research Team at KTH). I‚Äôll always remember the interesting workshops, discussions, collaborative efforts, and after-work celebrations with you all. I'm already nostalgic for the wonderful moments spent at the Department of Software and Computer Systems at KTH.

Thanks to my colleagues from the Financial Crime Prevention team at SEB for their support and encouragement to complete my Ph.D. studies.

Last but not least, huge thanks to the WASP ‚Äì Wallenberg AI, Autonomous Systems and Software Program (WASP) for funding my Ph.D. studies. WASP has brought amazing life-changing opportunities to so many good students in the world. The unique experiences and network I've built from this research program are invaluable.

Are you really sure you're running the software you think you are? I'm not. Our recent paper on the Software Bill of Materials (SBOMs) reveals strong interest and activity in this research area for software supply chain security. Our paper highlights technical weaknesses in the current foundation of SBOMs, including incorrect or incomplete dependency trees. These findings emphasize the need for further work on clarifying SBOM standards and improving the quality of output from SBOM producers in the Java ecosystem. Let's unleash the full potential of SBOMs to improve software security and reliability! Check out our paper for more details üìë https://lnkd.in/dV5h3UTn
